description:
Maya had already found a dream home in Lower Saxony, but unfortunately, contrary to expectations, it turned out that she can't stand cats. We had, of course, tried it out here at the animal shelter beforehand, and her reaction didn't allow for any negative conclusions. However, animals can behave quite differently in a private household than in a shelter, especially when they begin to feel at home and become more confident. Now our Maya is back at the shelter and is starting a new attempt to find a home without furry roommates or other animals in general.
Maya originally came to us after being confiscated for violating the Animal Welfare Act. She is a very lively and people-oriented dog who wants plenty of exercise. She especially enjoys playing foraging games. She knows basic commands and is house-trained. She lets other dogs walk her around calmly, but she doesn't want any more contact with other dogs. In her youthful exuberance, her temper sometimes gets a bit out of hand—she doesn't mean any harm, but occasionally unintentionally becomes a bit rowdy. Therefore, it's very important that the person at the other end of the leash is a) steady and b) when in doubt, "friendly and assertive." Maya is sometimes a bit clumsy and doesn't show enough consideration for people.
We would like this charming bundle of energy to find a home with active people who have plenty of time for her. Any children should be at least 14 years old; she is absolutely not suitable for smaller/younger children. Please note that, depending on the breed, a landlord's permit is usually required, and depending on the state, muzzles and leashes may automatically be required in public. Maya is currently unable to climb stairs due to cruciate ligament problems, so a ground-level home would be ideal.
Would you like to give Maya a lovely home or do you have any questions? Please contact her animal caretakers at Benji House by phone at +49 30 76 888-212 or fill out the form below. We look forward to hearing from you!

The beautiful Bonny was given to us by her previous owners for personal reasons. Now this very sweet and lively dog is looking for a new home.
Bonny will only be rehomed in a rural home with a garden. Children living in the household should be at least 14 years old.

Rubble is currently in a foster home.
Rubble originally came to us at Sonnenhof with his mother, Pauline, and his five siblings at the age of about three weeks. Since then, he's been through quite a bit: After a short stay in a new home and with a foster family, Rubble severely injured his leg and had to undergo multiple surgeries.
In new situations and around strangers, Rubble is initially insecure and often reacts by barking. He needs time to gain trust and likes to decide for himself when to allow closeness. However, once he has established a bond, he is cuddly, eager to learn, and full of joy for life.
For Rubble, we are looking for people with heart and mind who are willing to accompany him on his special journey, provide him with the necessary care, and accept him as he is. Attending dog training would be very helpful for his further development and is encouraged by us.
shelter_name: Sonnenhof für Mensch und Tier, eine Einrichtung vom Deutschen Tierschutzbund e.V.

description:
Seit 2023 wartet Bingo bereits im Tierheim auf ein neues Zuhause. Eine viel zu lange Zeit, denn besonders in Bingos Alter ist jeder Moment kostbar und jeder weitere Tag im Tierheim ein Tag zu viel. Hier wird der liebenswerte Mischlingsrüde natürlich von Pflegern und Gassigehern auf Händen getragen und wir versuchen ihm die Wartezeit möglichst schön zu gestalten – Sozialkontakte mit weiteren Artgenossen und uns Zweibeinern, sowie ausgiebige Spaziergänge und Leckereien… und trotzdem kann selbst die beste Pflege und Fürsorge hier kein eigenes Zuhause ersetzen.
Weshalb der hübsche Kerl noch bei uns ist, bleibt jedoch ein Rätsel. Einige Adoptanten sind auf der Suche nach einem bereits älteren, gesetzten Hund für kurze Gassirunden, doch ist Bingo hier für meisten „noch zu fit“. Natürlich sieht und merkt man ihm sein Alter inzwischen auch an. Er hat bereits ein paar graue Haare, das ein oder andere Lipom und auch der Blick wird zunehmend trüb – doch genießt Bingo seine Spaziergänge noch immer in vollen Zügen. Getreu dem Motto „Wer Rastet der Rostet“ sind auch seine ehrenamtlichen Gassigeher fleißig dabei, den Herrn in Bewegung zu Halten. Selbst noch ein Stündchen am Stück und einen zügigen Schritt kann der Spanier noch getrost mithalten. Mit genügend Sport und Muskelaufbau bleiben wir optimistisch, dass ihn diese Fitness noch einige Zeit begleiten wird.
Andere Familien wünschen sich wiederum einen lernwilligen Jungspund, den man „leichter“ erziehen kann als einen älteren Hund. Natürlich kann Bingo trotz seiner aufgeweckten, aktiven Art keinen Teenager ersetzen, doch lernen und beschäftigt werden kann er noch immer. Der große Agilitystar schlummert nicht mehr in ihm, doch ist dies auch bei den meisten jüngeren, Durchnittshaushunden eher selten der Fall. Für kleineres Gehirnjogging, wie Leckerliesuchen oder einfache Spielereien ist Bingo, besonders im Blick auf die leckere Belohnung, stehts zu haben. Auch kleinere Tricks kann er auch mit 13 Jahren noch lernen.
Nun suchen wir nocheinmal ganz deutlich nach einem passenden Deckel für Bingo. Natürlich hat auch er Eigenheiten, Ecken und Kanten – wie jedes atmende Wesen. Auch er kann mal an der Leinen andere Hunde anpflaumen, doch geht es meistens ohne TamTam. Auch er kann im Laufe des Lebens noch gesundheitliche Probleme entwickeln, doch ist er aktuell noch fit. Alles in Allem ein ganz normaler Hund – nur leider mit etwas mehr Zeitdruck auf der Suche nach einem neuen Zuhause, als manch jüngerer Vierbeiner.

Our Maurice has been found. He is a funny but also very self-confident dog and is looking for a home with experience with dogs, or ideally terriers.
Maurice is people-oriented, house-trained, and calmly leads past other dogs. He knows basic commands and enjoys food-search games. Whether he can be left alone for a while needs to be tested and, if necessary, practiced patiently.
Maurice is a bit moody—he might be happy about something one moment, but growl the next. People who provide him with security but also consistency are important to him. We suspect he could also move in with an existing first female dog—this would have to be tested. Younger children should not live in the household.
Please note that several visits will be necessary to get to know Maurice.

Gulliver found his way to us after life in his previous home wasn't as harmonious as we had imagined when he was adopted many years ago. Initially, minor issues, which many dog owners are confronted with over time, quickly escalated, and what started as a minor issue developed into a highly reactive elephant that put the continued cohabitation to the test.
Many behaviors become ingrained over time, both in the dog and its owners. Negative experiences create tension and fear, which reinforces pessimistic expectations that make it difficult to stay motivated and optimistic during training. Now the black male is getting a complete "reset," and together we are embarking on his journey into a carefree future.
The animal shelter had previously shown little of the insecure, yet explosive nature of this exciting mixed-breed dog. The bright male quickly settled in and got used to his caregivers. With our relaxed, yet firm demeanor, we were able to quickly convince Gulliver of our leadership qualities. This sensitive fellow once again demonstrated his keen sense for the emotions of his two-legged friends. Whether tense or relaxed, Gulliver reads his companion like a book and clearly reflects their emotional state. On walks, you can see that good preparatory work has already been done with him. If he is led consistently, he walks relaxed beside you on a loose leash and voluntarily orients himself towards his owner – a good foundation for further training.
We are currently regularly practicing dog encounters, but even there he is making rapid progress and scores points with his responsiveness in stressful situations. If you give him too much leeway outside, he likes to go along with whatever he wants. Be it pedestrians who he fixates on from a distance and barks at, or strange dogs who he also barks at. That's why it's important to have the right standing and to recognize and manage critical situations early on.

Ridgeback Rüde Kronos, oder liebevoll auch nur „der Papa“ genannt, kam zusammen mit einer ebenfalls unkastrierten Hündin und deren 10 Söhne und Töchtern zu uns. Zu seiner Vergangenheit gibt es leider sonst nicht all zu viele Infos, nur sein Chip hat uns sein Herkunftsland, die Niederlande, verraten. Der Rest bleibt zum größten Teil Spekulation basierend auf seinem anfänglichen Charakter und der Auffindesituation.




Ein Halsband zu tragen, an einer Leine zu laufen oder sich auch einfach nur anfassen zu lassen war anfangs bereits eine große Herausforderung. Auch das Durchatmen und mal chillen fällt ihm noch schwer und wird sicherlich künftig noch einiges an Zeit und Arbeit kosten – es bleibt jedoch unabdingbar, um ihm die Teilnahme an einem entspannten Alltag ermöglichen zu können.
We took Inge in as a stray at the dog shelter in April. She had been found tied up in poor condition, emaciated, and with an inflamed eye.
shelter_name: Aktiv für Hunde in Not e.V.

description: After moving from a Romanian animal shelter, little Prada found a new home in Germany. Over time, the initially insecure, calm dog thawed out and gradually took over the reins in her new world. Unfortunately, she lacked experience in dealing with her exaggerated self-awareness, and so, without guidance from her humans, Prada increasingly lost herself in the inappropriate role of boss of the house. Her staff were reprimanded and reprimanded accordingly, which ended with the occasional biting incident in her last home.

Husky dog Hannah does her breed proud. She loves going for walks, preferably for long ones. She walks perfectly on a leash – unless you stand still for too long, which she, as a Husky, finds completely unnecessary.
Hannah is people-oriented, doesn't shy away from anything, and loves to learn. She also loves children, so she could easily become a family dog.
Hannah already knows some basic commands, can ride in the car without any problems, and has already experienced a domestic environment.
Hannah gets along well with other dogs.

Our big, fluffy Kangal, Bumi, has had some ups and downs in his life. Born in an animal shelter and unfortunately raised in a deprived youth, his start was extremely difficult. Fortunately, after being placed with his new family, he was able to catch up on a lot, which has allowed him to develop into a wonderful, albeit cautious, companion.


On the leash, he knows full well that other two- and four-legged creatures are of no interest and is not easily unsettled. Even walks with other shelter residents are no problem for this big man - it is only when they live directly together on the shelter grounds that his stoic livestock guardian becomes apparent again. Bumi can happily do without other dogs in the rest of his everyday life and prefers to spend time on his own rather than sharing the attention of his caregivers, basket, or food. In the past, Bumi has shown that he would particularly defend food and chews from other dogs or children, which is why we would rather see him in a quiet household without other dogs and children.
Bumi longs for a new home where he can settle in and blossom again. Regular exercise would help not only his soul but also his body to stay healthy. Unfortunately, Bumi was diagnosed with hip dysplasia – a deformity of the hip that unfortunately affects many dogs these days. The deformation of the hip joint cannot be reversed, but with the help of targeted exercise, muscle building, and physiotherapy, dogs can be supported so that they can walk pain-free for as long as possible and the problems do not worsen. Since Bumi loves to splash around, especially in warm weather, a swim or two would be a good idea in addition to walks to give him some exercise.

Young Kiez has experienced quite a bit of turmoil and instability in the past. Even as a puppy, Kiez's life started turbulently, because while most puppies go to their new families alone, she embarked on a big journey with a sibling. For the two of them, it was constant partying. They could run wild with their playful antics, and training or learning to be calm steadily took a backseat. Spurred on by her peer, Kiez lived only for forwards – higher, faster, further – until all the commotion at home became too much for everyone when the two-legged members of her family's circumstances changed.
Well-intentioned, but unfortunately very impulsive and lacking in planning, Kiez was sent to live with acquaintances to spare her a stop at the animal shelter. Within a day, the offer of help turned into her own cry for help, because the bundle of energy, for whom stability and boundaries had always been foreign concepts, quickly became overwhelmed in her new environment. Since she was only ever known for her cheerful, playful nature, she was thrown straight into the thick of things, skipping over the crucial settling-in period. This ultimately led to Kiez completely losing it. Within a single day, everyone had the opportunity to interact with Kiez's teeth if she didn't know how to gracefully extricate herself from an exciting situation. And her motto remained "only forward," meaning there was no going back to her first home. With a dog who was now not only hyperactive but had even bitten someone, suddenly no one wanted to take responsibility anymore, and so she inevitably ended up at our animal shelter. Here, Kiez can finally take a deep breath so we can address the root of the problems, because Kiez is by no means a dangerous or malicious dog. This motivated Labrador retriever gets excited easily and would do almost anything for a treat. Seemingly well-behaved, but behind the funny facade lies not true training, but rather a kind of dressage. Sit, stay, go on the blanket, or walk backward – none of that is a problem. Simply doing nothing, relaxing, calming down, or not being the center of attention is much more appealing. It's easy to be tempted to push her further, because the pretty little thing is undeniably cute. Kiez has a lot to process and is learning to accept boundaries for the first time; it's all very stressful, and for such energetic dogs, it's a far better form of exercise than any obstacle course. Currently, we often have to manage her in everyday life until Kiez is ready in training to do it independently. The training process is certainly frustrating for both human and dog, but it's essential for a relaxed future for everyone. Gradually, the penny drops, and Kiez is able to remain increasingly calm even in tense situations. It's certainly still a long way to the relaxed "picture-perfect Labrador," but we are confident that with appropriate guidance, we can steer the young lady toward becoming a suitable everyday companion. You reap what you sow, and so the focus will now be on planting the delicate seeds of frustration tolerance and impulse control.

Nokart has been found. He is a personable, lively, and very self-confident fellow. He knows basic commands and is house-trained. When out for walks, he calmly lets himself be led past other dogs.
At our veterinary practice, he will receive free lifelong treatment for his musculoskeletal system because he has problems walking. He also has a condition called megaesophagus (enlargement of the esophagus), which prevents food from being transported properly to the stomach. Therefore, he must be fed while standing almost vertically, otherwise he will vomit his food. We have found a good solution for this and are happy to advise you. He will receive free lifelong treatment for this and his arthritis at our veterinary practice.
Nokart does not cope well with frustration. As a result, he quickly becomes angry and tries to snap or bite the leash. He is looking for people with experience with this breed. Although he can live in the city, he needs a very quiet, single-story home without children. He can no longer climb stairs. Whether he is suitable as a second dog needs to be tested.
If you would like to meet Nokart or have any questions about him, please contact his animal caretakers at +49 30 76888-220 or fill out the form below. Please plan several visits to the shelter to get to know him in peace. We look forward to hearing from you.

The pretty Australian Shepherd Moxy found her way to us via another animal welfare organization. At first, she was rather reserved and shy around us keepers. She had to settle in and get used to her new surroundings.
Winning Moxy over is quite a lot of work. Her ice is very thick, and it takes a lot of patience and nerve to melt it. Until then, Moxy is skeptical of her counterpart and sets clear rules. These, of course, tend to be in her favor and are enforced, if necessary with the help of her 42 augments. But she's worth it! Every milestone, sometimes hard work, reveals a new, endearing facet of this pretty Aussie lady. Once she's gained trust in her humans, she's open and enthusiastic, loves to be cuddled and have fun together.


Overall, with Moxy, it's important to always stay on track - even if she's just letting go. All this effort will surely cost her a few gray hairs, but it's worth it. Moxy is excited about her new phase of life and will bring this joy into her two-legged friends' everyday lives.

Woody came to us when his life path was leading him in the wrong direction. If the necessary upbringing is neglected at a young age, it can take its toll later in life - as was the case with this charming Romanian. He knows how to use his big eyes to his advantage and he also finds a way to get his way. If an endearing look and witty antics aren't enough to avoid possible consequences, he uses his entire repertoire of threatening gestures and also knows how to deploy his 42 sparkling white arguments.
In general, Woody sees himself more in the position of referee than in the role of player. Just because he doesn't want to follow the rules himself doesn't mean that his humans don't have to. He hands out yellow and red cards as he sees fit. To underline this position, he has claimed all kinds of resources for himself in the past. From his own food to his owner's food and bed. Woody deliberately seeks out such conflicts in order to test his boundaries again or to redefine them.
Of course, this high-flying lifestyle cannot continue – the little king is fully aware of this – which is why a lot of training is now on the agenda. Such a difficult and responsible task doesn't really suit him. The young male has bright, relaxed, and eager-to-learn sides, but he can only fully develop these sides once the burden of having to control everything at all times is lifted from his shoulders. To achieve this, he is now undergoing the unpopular and labor-intensive training.
The little man is searching for his place in society. And for a human partner who will accept the odd gray hair until he achieves success. Throughout his life, Woody has succeeded in making progress with sustainability and stubbornness. It'll take a while to rewrite this success story. Two steps forward, one step back – and yet progress has already been made. Now all that's missing is the right home, where we're ready to continue the training and show Woody how relaxed and fun the world can be when he lets himself get involved.

Hello, I'm Mads. I always try very hard to please my owners. Unfortunately, new situations scare me a lot, and I need a lot of encouragement. I'm very people-oriented anyway, especially if I know them well. Then I love to be cuddled – I can sometimes get a little boisterous out of sheer joy. I'm a bit skeptical of men for a long time. I take women much more quickly.
I ended up in the animal shelter because something really stupid happened. When I get food in my bowl, I don't recognize anything anymore. I guess that's called "resource guarding." And then I bit the other dog. When my previous owner tried to intervene, I unfortunately caught her too. If my bowl is empty, I don't have any problems at all. I also accept treats without any problems, and I'd gladly give them lots and lots again and again!
It would probably be good if my new owners knew about dogs – including my breed. And a good feeding plan would help ensure that something bad like this never happens again. That's why I'm better off being kept alone, even though I actually really love dogs. There shouldn't be any children in my home either. Better safe than sorry. The city could definitely be something for me. Since I'm one of the so-called "listed dogs," you definitely need a landlord's permit.
Phew—that's a lot of everything. Is there anyone who'd still like to get to know me? That would be great! The best way to find out is to call my animal caretakers

Ada ist eine wundervolle, ausgeglichene Persönlichkeit und auch optisch ein echter Blickfang. Mit einer Schulterhöhe von ca. 75 cm und einem dennoch schlanken und grazilen Körperbau beweist Ada, wie elegant ein Herdenschützer sein kann.
Die „Arbeitsweise“ hingegen wirft ein ganz anderes Licht auf die sonst so zarte Riesin. Typisch Kangal hat sie immer ein Auge auf alles, was vor ihrem Gehege oder der anderen Seite des Gartenzauns los ist. Wenn nötig, werden ungebetene Beobachter durch tiefes Bellen und ordentlich Radau aus ihrem Zuständigkeitsbereich verwiesen. Auch andere Hunde dürfen sich was anhören, wenn Ada in Pöbel-Laune ist. Natürlich liegt dies tief in ihrer Genetik verankert – was jedoch keine Ausrede sein darf, um mangelnde Erziehung zu rechtfertigen.

Our Woody came to the animal shelter because he is very jealous of food, and unfortunately, this bad habit led to a bite incident in his previous home. He is looking for people with experience with dogs who can address his behavior and with whom he can be his only prince.
Woody knows the common basic commands, rides on the bus/train, and can even be left alone for a few hours. He has lived with cats before—but outside, he tends to chase them, as well as other small animals and game. He is often suspicious, especially of strange men. He also dislikes loud, hectic children.
We hope for a committed, loving home for Woody with people who have experience with more difficult dogs. To get to know him, interested parties should plan several visits.
If you are interested or have any questions, please contact Woody's animal caretakers at +49 30 76 888-220. We look forward to hearing from you.

Please note: Nanuk is only suitable for a shelter-like environment. His new home must offer the opportunity to handle him with safety training (we trained him to wear a muzzle and leash without contact). A fence system is therefore necessary where Nanuk can be kept in contact with people, but still shielded from direct confrontation. A kennel (with a heated indoor enclosure) and, ideally, a dog room with outdoor access are ideal for this.
Nanuk came to the shelter after being confiscated. Lack of distance, petting, and being touched in general are not his thing—he likes it when everyone stays in his "dance zone." If you respect that, he will gain trust and be able to relax better. He loves being outside with his owner, sniffing the world around him.
Nanuk defends his food, is not a beginner's dog, and prefers owners with experience with the breed who can provide him with clear leadership and spend plenty of time together on outings. He is not suitable for a family with children. Please note that, due to his breed, he is subject to muzzle and leash requirements in Berlin, and a landlord's permit is required for his ownership. He will receive free lifelong treatment for spondylosis at our veterinary practice.
If you would like to give Nanuk a home, please contact his animal caretakers at Idefix-Haus at +49 30 76888-173. Please plan several visits to the shelter so you can get to know him in peace.

Arion is representative of many rescues gone wrong of small "surprise packages" in the form of young dogs or "puppies" (as they are so often falsely advertised) from Eastern Europe.


But what kind of dog arrived here back then? A large, proud herd protector, aware of his (original) task and, due to a lack of leadership, confidently carrying it out? No, absolutely not. Arion was completely in limbo. If he had learned one thing in his few years, it was that he couldn't rely on anyone, and that no one could give him stability or security. So, although he wasn't able to look after his system himself, he still felt compelled to take on this task.
Today, Arion lets go of the reins with the right people and behaves admirably. Relaxed cuddles or going for a walk are perfectly possible. Dogs and passersby are ignored, the leash is slack, and the dog trots relaxedly next to, behind, or sometimes in front of the owner, depending on the command. Of course, he is not an enthusiastic herding dog, but the herd protector still wants to please. Arion knows who he can rely on, but he also knows who he cannot rely on, who doesn't have the right charisma. Here, he quickly falls back into old patterns. Dogs and passersby are attacked, and it quickly becomes dangerous for the person at the other end of the leash.

Buddy was given to us because his previous owners' living conditions didn't suit his needs.


When Buddy gets stressed, he tends to bark. In his previous home, this led to Buddy barking in many situations outside, especially when he encountered other dogs. Even leaving him alone at home wasn't possible, as Buddy would protest loudly.
At our animal shelter, the picture is somewhat different. Of course, there are situations in which Buddy barks, but overall, Buddy is very easy to lead by his caregivers. He has completely stopped barking when meeting other dogs and is otherwise very well-oriented and cooperative. He enjoys long walks and is a very active dog who needs plenty of exercise but also wants to be mentally challenged.

Kiko has been found. This people-oriented and very lively male is house-trained, knows basic commands, and can be calmly led past other dogs. However, he is also unruly and still likes to jump up at people. The owner at the other end of the leash should therefore be able to hold the large and strong Kiko, who weighs 36 kg. Attending dog training school is important for him. He is not yet able to be left alone at all – that will require a lot of training and patience.
For Kiko, we are looking for dog-experienced, athletic people in a household without children. He can certainly also move in as a second dog – it's a matter of mutual understanding between the dogs.
If you would like to meet Kiko, please contact his animal care team at +49 30 76888-264 or fill out the form below. We look forward to your inquiry.

Female Gracie
Age: 5 years (born March 16, 2020)
Gender: Female
Gracie and Grando (see last picture, also listed under males) are one and the same, so they should only find a new home together.

Charlie has a very chaotic and insecure past. Fleeing and escaping from frightening situations hasn't always brought him the desired results in his life so far. When initial threats and growling didn't help him, the first biting incident occurred in a confining situation. It wasn't until he got to the animal shelter that he was able to build trust in himself and his two-legged friends, which helps him keep a cool head in many situations.
Diligent training, time, patience, and exposure to many different environmental influences have turned Charlie into a completely new dog. The shadows of his past have increasingly faded, and his insecure self only rarely comes to the fore.
The little Romanian has now become a perfectly plausible everyday companion dog, provided he receives appropriate guidance. Because Charlie now knows his worth and is willing to voice his opinion (even without being asked). If he's given too much freedom on the leash, he'll bark at strange dogs or passersby. If someone nevertheless ventures too close to him, he might respond with his 42 "arguments." Unannounced visitors have also experienced this bad mood in the past, which is why such situations still require some management. However, once Charlie has understood his place and that he won't be disturbed by strangers there, he can easily accept these spatial restrictions and withdraw.
From the very beginning, Charlie spent his time at the shelter with other dogs. Initially, the focus was on coaxing the shy guy out of his shell a little with more relaxed companions. In the meantime, however, he's become a solid, socially competent cornerstone for many dog groups for us, too. Sometimes in large, diverse groups, sometimes in shared apartments with two, the Romanian has proven to be a reliable companion. Together, he can make everyday life in the shelter much more colorful, and he can be encouraged to play around, but he can also calm down on his own and communicate when things get too hectic. Therefore, adoption with an existing first-time dog is a good option.

Araxa is truly unique. As a result of an injury, Araxa's lower lip is no longer fully fused, which makes her look very special. However, this minor handicap doesn't bother or affect Araxa at all. Her future owners should simply place a towel next to the water bowl, because drinking with a lip like that isn't quite as elegant.
Araxa, as is typical of the breed, bonds closely with her caregivers. She enjoys going for walks, already has good basic obedience, and can run off-leash. The senior also enjoys small activities.

Tabaluga kam zu uns ins Tierheim, da sich die privaten Umstände in der Familie geändert haben und auch die Suche nach einem Platz im näheren Bekanntenkreis leider erfolglos blieb. Die neue Situation und der Umzug verunsicherten den Mischlingsrüden erst einmal und er wusste nicht so recht, wohin mit sich. Er suchte oft die Nähe zu uns Pfleger:innen und wir gaben ihm den nötigen Halt. Nun darf er in Ruhe bei uns ankommen und sich an die neue Umgebung gewöhnen.
Im Alltag und besonders draußen zeigt er sich aktuell nicht besonders umweltsicher. Er ist zwar grundsätzlich kein unsicherer oder ängstlicher Hund, vieles bereitet ihm aber Sorge. Dass er kein so armer Knopf ist, wie manche Personen zu Beginn denken, zeigt er recht schnell. Denn wenn er eins kann, dann ist es imponieren. Wenn es nach ihm ginge, so wäre kein Baum und kein Grashalm auf der Strecke unmarkiert – zur Sicherheit am besten mehrfach. Kommt es zu frontalen Begegnungen mit Hunden, Fahrradfahrern oder Joggern, verbellt er diese sehr vehement.
Abgesehen davon zeigt Tabaluga beim Spaziergang insgesamt eine solide Grunderziehung. Er läuft gut an der Leine, kennt den Rückruf, an dessen Verbindlichkeit zwar noch gearbeitet werden muss, und orientiert sich in reizarmen Situationen insgesamt gut an seinem Menschen.
Seine Ambivalenz zeigt sich vor allem im Umgang mit anderen Hunden. Steht eine intakte, meinungsstarke Hündin vor ihm, backt Tabaluga sicherheitshalber ganz kleine Brötchen. Dann hält er Abstand, ist höflich und deeskalierend, statt etwas zu riskieren. Hat er aber einen Rüden vor sich, der sich ebenso zurückhaltend verhält, wie er bei einer Hündin, wächst er über sich hinaus – und das nicht auf die gute Weise. Wird er hier nicht gebremst, sucht er den Konflikt. Selbst wenn sein Gegenüber ganz klar zeigt, dass er keinen Streit sucht, sondern sich immer wieder deeskalierend abwendet.

Die kleine Donna kam nach einigem Hin und Her zu uns ins Tierheim und ist nun bereit wieder nach vorne zu sehen, statt sich in der Vergangenheit zu verstecken. Als Welpe aufgenommen, nach der Trennung weiter gereicht, um dann doch nach mehreren Jahren zurück geholt zu werden... Einen konstanten Faden kannte Donnas Leben bisher kaum und das hin und her wurde ihr (und ihren Zweibeinern) schnell zu viel.

Hundeomi Futomaki hat plötzlich und unerwartet ihr letztes Zuhause verloren und wartet nun bei uns darauf erneut entdeckt zu werden. 2012 erblickte sie in Kroatien das Licht der Welt und durfte damals gemeinsam mit ihren Zweibeinern die Koffer packen, um nach Deutschland zu ziehen – nun stehen wir ihr an ihrer Seite, um den hoffentlich letzten Umzug ihres Lebens zu ermöglichen.
Die schwarze Mischlingshündin (mit den mittlerweile auch grauen Häärchen) ist auf dem ersten Blick eine eher unscheinbare Hündin. Sicherlich auch dem fortschreitenden Alter geschuldet genießt sie zunehmend die Zeit im Körbchen und fordert neben den ausgiebigen Streicheleinheiten auch ihre Entspannungszeiten ein. Doch gibt es selbst im Leben der Seniorin noch Phasen, in denen man ihr den Schalk im Nacken anmerkt. Wie auch bei den Menschen fehlt ihr ab und an noch das Verständnis für „die Jugend von heute“. Auch, wenn sie den Umgang mit Kindern kennt, sind ihr Roller oder Skateboards nicht ganz so geheuer. Hier verleiht sie ihrem Unverständnis auch mal lautstark Ausdruck und kann Pöbeln, wie man es ihr niemals zugetraut hätte. Zum Glück kehrt nach einer solchen Meinungsäußerung auch genauso schnell wieder Ruhe ein und Futomaki kann den restlichen Gassigang wieder genießen, als wäre nie etwas passiert.

Unfortunately, the sensitive mixed-breed dog Crassus is not as self-confident as his name initially suggests. A lack of security and leadership have led him to put himself in the front row and assume the role of "boss" – a position he is uncomfortable with and which further increases his insecurity. Unfortunately, he has never been able to learn how to avoid conflicts or resolve them without stress, which is why only "flight" or a staged "attack" come to mind. If his counterpart appears very self-confident, Crassus is rather subdued. Inhibited people, on the other hand, make the mixed-breed very insecure.
Crassus has now adjusted to his new routine at the animal shelter and is actively involved in training. The lively dog clearly enjoys practicing with his caregivers and enjoys the mental stimulation during walks. Even though training is still completely new territory for Crassus, he tries very hard to please his trainers and is making steady progress. Despite everything, training is an ongoing process, and it takes time to transform an insecure "leash bully" into a relaxed and everyday companion. It's time and effort, however, that are worth it and will determine the future relationship between human and dog.
Even though Crassus now responds well to the guidance of his caregivers, he knows exactly what's important to him. Food is a particularly important resource for Crassus, one that he also defended in his last home. He has since learned, step by step, to hold back and wait for permission to eat instead of immediately pouncing on anything edible. Asking questions and being guided by his caregivers is an important task for this guy, and is also regularly practiced during walks. It helps him to hold back and not always see himself as the one in charge. Even during dog encounters, he's becoming increasingly reliable at maintaining his composure, utilizing the support of his leaders.
Becoming this leader requires sensitivity and patience to gain the cautious male's trust. Once this has been achieved, the path to a shared future is paved.

Male Grando
Age: 12 years (born June 16, 2013)
Gender: Male
Grando and Gracie (see last picture, also found under female dogs) are one and the same, so they should only find a new home together.

Ohja, unser Rainer ist der absolute Wahnsinn! Ein wahnsinnig schöner, energetischer Rüde mit wahnsinnig viel Potential für das es aber auch noch einen wahnsinnig langen und wahnsinnig anstrengenden Trainingsweg zu beschreiten gibt, bis man dieses voll entfalten kann.




Neben den allgemeinen Trainingsansätzen gibt es jedoch auch in den Arbeitsbereichen des Drahthaares weiteren Nachholbedarf. Wer sich in Punkto „rassespezifischer Beschäftigung“ auf Dummyarbeit freut wird hier zuerst noch die Fehler der Vergangenheit ausradieren müssen. Das Ziel einer ruhigen, konzentrierten Teamarbeit immer vor Augen kann man mit steigender Bindung und Selbstregulation sicherlich Einiges erreichen, den empfänglich wäre Rainer schon für das Apportieren – fast schon zu viel… Aktuell verliert sich Rainer Wahnsinn noch sehr in der Dynamik und schaukelt sich in einem wahren Suchtverhalten immer weiter hoch. Was er mal, mit Apportel im Maul, genau damit anstellen soll weiß Rainer bisher noch nicht oder ignoriert es gekonnt. Die Beute wird lieber verschleppt und in die Mangel genommen, statt sie mit seinem Zweibeiner zu teilen.

Mixed-breed dog Paletti unfortunately has a very typical backstory. She came to Germany from Bulgaria at just a few weeks old and was adopted through another association. From the very beginning, there were minor and major problems, but within her well-established environment, things remained largely calm for the rapidly growing lady, even without training. Due to the advanced age of her previous owners and the associated changes in their daily lives, Paletti ultimately had to move to our animal shelter after the rehoming association saw no other way to find a home for her.
By moving her to us, we are now trying to break the downward spiral in Paletti's life. Unfortunately, Paletti found it difficult for a long time to build a trusting relationship with us and overcome her initial tension. Although she had regularly attended a dog daycare center in the past and was already familiar with being in an enclosure and kennel surrounded by other four-legged friends, it took her a surprisingly long time to settle in. Paletti therefore loves going outside the most. When she's out for a walk, she finds it much easier to switch off and distract herself with the views of the fields and parks. She also enjoys cooperating with her owners, even if they currently feel more like a "means to an end" than a fully-fledged caregiver. Well, in short: a typical livestock guardian dog. Initially skeptical and reserved – but actually looking for close social contacts, which we will hopefully soon be able to provide.
For many, however, the dog seems a little ambivalent, and even for us, it was difficult to assess this fine lady at first. Curious, bribable, relaxed, funny, but also at times disinterested or overwhelmed by the unfamiliar surroundings. In the past, there were always set routines, and from a young age, her life took place in her own little world, the house and yard. Aside from trips to doggie daycare, there was little variety in Paletti's routine, as the young livestock guardian could do without visitors, small animals, or other hustle and bustle – something her previous owners did as well. With her natural vocation as a guard dog, this pretty girl can also learn that there are breaks and evenings off, during which she can let her owners decide who is allowed to enter and leave the property and when. She naturally enjoys analyzing her surroundings and is always aware of everything that's happening around her, but with reasonable guidance, she too can understand that there's no reason to interfere.
As her training progresses and old habits are abandoned, we hope, in collaboration with suitable prospective owners, to develop a great future for Paletti, even though the adoption prospects for most adult livestock guardian mixes are already worse than for most other breeds.

Simba is a lively German Shepherd. Unfortunately, his previous owners were overwhelmed with him, so he came to us. Indeed, handsome Simba still has a lot to learn. His keepers are diligently training him to walk on a leash and ignore other dogs.
Young Simba is already quite capable. He is house-trained, knows basic commands, and can even stay alone for up to four hours. He is very attached to his people and loves food games.
We are looking for a loving home for our boisterous Simba, preferably on the outskirts of town. Children living in the household should be at least 14 years old. Simba needs consistent people who have experience with German Shepherds. Attending dog training is important for him. Several visits to our home will be necessary to get to know each other.
Would you like to give our Simba a home? Then we look forward to your call at 030 76888-264 or fill out the inquiry form below.

My name is Blue, and I was surrendered to the Schwebheim animal shelter because I can't be left alone yet. Typical for my breed, I'm very agile and like to be kept busy. Larger, stable children would be no problem for me. I get along well with other dogs, depending on how well they get along. I'm house-trained and very playful. I enjoy riding in the car, have a strong hunting instinct, and can open doors. I've never met a cat. I still need to work on my leash skills. Dog training is recommended.

Tabitia was born in October 2022 and arrived at the Bucov shelter as a puppy. As the smallest in her kennel, she didn't have it easy. But since January 2022, she has been living in one of our foster homes in Unterschneidheim. She has since gotten used to people. She gets along great with the other dogs in the foster home and is enjoying life. If you are interested, send us a short email. We will then put you in touch with our foster home.

Joey also comes from Slovakia. He's more of a cautious and reserved type. He approaches very gently to make contact. He patiently stays in the background until it's his turn. He then loves to be petted and cuddled. He is very tolerant and confident towards other dogs and avoids any conflict. A wonderful dog who will surely become a great family member. You can arrange an appointment by email at buero@tierheim-tuttlingen.de.

Gero was secured and rehomed—but unfortunately, he bit. This handsome dog is looking for a home with experienced people.
Gero loves foraging games. He is very alert and docile, knows basic commands, and is easily motivated with food. Unfortunately, in conflict situations, he tends to turn away.
We are looking for a home for Gero with people who have experience with his breed and more difficult dogs. Gero is not suited to the noisy city, so a house with a fenced yard in a quieter area would be perfect. Children should not live in the household. Whether he would be suitable as a second dog to an existing female dog would have to be tested based on their compatibility.
Would you like to meet Gero or do you have any questions about him? Please contact his animal caretakers at +49 30 76 888-204 or fill out the inquiry form below. We look forward to hearing from you.

Gördi is a highly motivated and very active young dog who has the best potential for athletic owners with good previous experience – ideally with Dobermans or similar breeds.
Gördi desires constructive exercise that taps into his strengths – he is fast, athletic, eager to please, and generally friendly, but also excitable, towards his environment. At the same time, however, he is also adolescently uninhibited, demanding, and has a very low frustration threshold – so we are specifically looking for people for him who will encourage and challenge him, actively exercise him, but also practice calm and promote relaxation.
Gördi absolutely needs steadfast and confident people at his side, whom he can trust and whom he can leave to make decisions about situations. Gördi is clever and tends to question people and their rules when unsure, but responds wonderfully to clear, consistent instruction.
Unfortunately, we don't currently see Gördi as a family dog. Young people with very solid dog experience would be conceivable, but this would have to be discussed in detail.

Tommy is a neutered, approximately 46 cm tall mixed-breed male (probably a Husky). He is approximately 11 months old.
He is very intelligent and eager to learn. Tommy also has excellent social skills with all other dogs. His distinctive feature is one bicolored eye.
For more information about this lovely fellow, please call us or schedule an appointment by calling +49 2333 72068.

Kolja is a very lively dog and came to us as a temporary home. He calmly lets other dogs walk past him and already knows basic commands. He's always enthusiastic about foraging games, and we would describe him as a very personable dog. Whether he's house-trained and can be left alone sometimes needs to be tested and, if necessary, patiently trained.
Kolja is a man's dog—he ignores women but likes to test them out. His biggest problem is that he defends food and resources. His new home should have experience with this issue in addition to his breed. He needs a quiet, rural environment.
Typical for the breed, Kolja needs plenty of mental and physical stimulation and therefore active people who will show him life. Children should not live in the household, but we can imagine Kolja with a female dog, depending on their affinity. Please note that several visits will be necessary to get to know Kolja.
If you would like to give Kolja a home or have any questions about him, please contact us by phone at 030 76888-264 or fill out the inquiry form below.

Roxy - vorsichtige Hündin sucht geduldige Menschen mit Herz und Erfahrung🧡
Roxy hat ihr Zuhause verloren, weil sie einen stark ausgeprägten Jagdtrieb hat - in ihrem früheren Zuhause kam es leider zu einem Vorfall mit zwei Enten. Ein gut gesichertes Grundstück hätte das verhindern können, und genau das ist nun eine wichtige Voraussetzung für ihr neues Zuhause.
Roxy ist sehr scheu und braucht lange, um Vertrauen zu fassen. Fremden gegenüber ist sie zurückhaltend, oft unsicher, aber bei uns zeigt sie sich nicht aggressiv. Sie zieht sich lieber zurück, statt sich durch Angst verteidigen zu wollen. Hat sie erst einmal Vertrauen gefasst, zeigt sie sich freundlich und ruhig.
Wichtig:

We originally adopted young Benny along with other young dogs from another animal welfare organization. He had already briefly found a new home, where things unfortunately didn't work out, and now found his way back to us.
Benny appeared friendly, curious, and open to strangers after a short introduction. After a brief assessment, he usually reacts to new environmental stimuli with great interest. In stressful and overwhelming situations, Benny tends to release his energy by chewing. This is difficult to stop him from doing and, in the past, has sometimes reacted with aggressive defensive behavior in these situations. Furthermore, resources, such as food and toys, are sometimes an issue with Benny, especially in relation to other dogs. We are already working with him on this issue. He is consistently cooperative, willing to learn, and enjoys working with his caregivers. Benny gets along well with other dogs.
We are looking for a home for Benny with people who are experienced with dogs and willing to continue working with the young male. Attendance at a dog school would be advisable and is desired by us.

description:
Rita, our dear German Shepherd, was reluctantly given up due to illness. Whether she's compatible with an existing dog can be tested if necessary. However, we believe that, given her history, Rita would prefer to be an only princess again. She loves the water and enjoys walks even in the rain. This makes her a perfect partner for nature-loving people. A wonderful companion with her gentle and sensitive nature.
Rita is a true treasure and is waiting for a loving home where she can settle down.

Atze has developed tremendously during his time with us. He responds extremely well to body language corrections and guidance and has learned to tolerate frustration and trust his owners. He is an open-minded, intelligent, eager-to-learn, and affectionate dog. Atze is currently living in a foster home where he is continuing to work with him on his specific needs. He now handles various situations (e.g., crowds, vehicles, movement stimuli) that previously unsettled him and caused him to redirect his attention to people with great confidence. He is sociable with other dogs, and it's welcome to have a confident dog already present, but this isn't necessary. We are looking for people with experience with the breed who will continue to work with him calmly, patiently, and consistently, as this will make Atze a truly wonderful companion. Since he has a tendency to overreact to movement stimuli, this should of course not be stimulated by additional ball games, throwing sticks or using a teaser.

The two-year-old Appenzeller Sennenhund Yoschi was given up because his first owners separated. Unfortunately, the rehoming was only short-lived because the new owner was unable to afford the necessary training for the young male.
The "Appenzeller Sennenhund" breed originates from farm dogs that were used in the Swiss Alps as driving, herding, and guard dogs. For this reason, an Appenzeller Sennenhund is not exactly a dog for beginners. Interested parties should be aware of this. Yoschi is a typical representative of his breed, brimming with energy and needs plenty of exercise accordingly.
Since Yoschi is still in his early stages of training, we are looking for people up to the task. Because of his still boisterous temperament, there should be no children in his new home. Yoschi is initially a bit skeptical of strangers, but quickly warms up once he gains trust and becomes an affectionate and playful young dog.

I'm Milko, and they didn't want me anymore. I was found tied up and taken to the animal shelter. Here I am now waiting.
At first, I was really quite unsure. But I've developed wonderfully, or at least that's what my keepers say. I know lots of great commands, I like to be bribed with treats, I walk well on a leash, and I get along great with other dogs. I've even become a real mediator among my fellow dogs. I like it when everyone gets along well!
I always want to please my humans, so I try my best. If I know and trust you, I'm your best friend. But I still find strangers really stupid. Since I'm a so-called "listed dog," I have to wear a muzzle. But I do that without any problems. In Berlin, my new owners need permission from their landlord.
I would like my new owners to have plenty of time for me. A house with a garden that's a bit out of the way would be great. The city is far too hectic for me. Children and cats shouldn't be part of my new family either. But I could imagine having a dog as a playmate. My owners would have to find out together whether I can be left alone and am house-trained, and practice if necessary.

Darius came to us as a found dog and has already returned to us twice from adoption. He is a gentle little fellow, approachable and sweet towards people – but he is very active and needs training. At first, he is a bit insecure – once he has a stable caregiver and a safe environment again, he will become more self-confident. It is important that his new owners spend enough time with him, stimulate him physically and mentally, and provide him with loving consistency in his training. Hunting imitation games should be avoided due to his breed-specific hunting instinct.
Darius is not yet very good at being alone. But that doesn't mean he can't learn. Nevertheless, it can be difficult for a single person to handle at first. With plenty of time and patience, he can hopefully gain enough trust to be left alone for short periods. In general, Darius loves to bark, which can naturally become a problem in an apartment building.
Darius forms a strong bond with his favorite people and wants to protect them – including his property. Children should not live in his home. However, we can imagine him as a confident first dog with a similar character. He would be overwhelmed in the city and needs a quiet residential area. Physical activity in an active family and attendance at dog training school are important to him.
If you would like to meet Darius or have any questions, please contact his animal caretakers at +49 30 76888-204 or fill out the inquiry form below. We look forward to hearing from you.
My name is Balu and I came to the animal shelter because of a seizure.

Why am I so happy? So happy, so happy... I'm extremely happy... I've never been so happy... I'm a happy-go-lucky person through and through. The sun shines on me every day. I prefer to keep quiet about my past and look positively to the future. I'm looking for loving people who want to stick with me through thick and thin... Speaking of fat, no, they're just heavy bones, but my carers have put me on a strict diet so I can start next summer with my bikini body. I'm looking for steadfast people who can handle over 34 kg of pure joy and love. Contact my staff at 0234/295950 and ask for Fee, affectionately known as Pummel Fee.

Boomer, male
Age: 12 months (born October 16, 2023)
Gender: male
For Boomer, we are looking for active two-legged friends who will train and guide him lovingly and with natural confidence, giving him a wonderful life. Information on compatibility with other dogs will follow.

My name is Fiete, and I came to the Schwebheim animal shelter as a surrendered dog. I'm initially a bit skeptical of strangers, but I'm easily persuaded with a toy. As is typical for my breed, I'm very agile and like to be kept busy, so I'm looking for new owners who are familiar with my breed. Older, stable children wouldn't be a problem for me. I get along with other dogs, depending on how well they get along. I still need to test out cats. I've already learned to walk on a leash. Otherwise, I would still recommend dog training.

Dietrich is a young, neutered mixed-breed male, born on February 28, 2023. He is a lovable, intelligent dog who still has a lot to learn. Dietrich has primarily lived in a kennel so far and is now looking for an experienced home that will provide him with the security and structure he needs.
Dietrich is playful and affectionate with his caregivers, but shows insecurity around strangers. If harassed, he may rush forward, which is why calm and experienced handling is important. He knows basic commands like "sit" and "down" and wears a muzzle when necessary.
Dietrich gets along well with other dogs, but cats and small animals should not live in his new home, as he has a strong hunting instinct. Children are also not suitable roommates for Dietrich – he may have had bad experiences in the past.
We are looking for a sensitive, child-free home for Dietrich with people who enjoy showing him the world with patience and consistency. With the right support and time, he will become a loyal companion with plenty of love to give.

Findus was found, so unfortunately we know nothing about his story. This handsome male is a lively, self-confident, and personable fellow. He reacts suspiciously towards strangers; he simply needs time to gain trust in new people. Findus is intelligent and very docile; handling him requires a great deal of sensitivity. He is a typical Rottweiler who takes his job as a guard very seriously and also acts accordingly self-confident. As a dog handler, you have to be able to cope with that. Despite his friendly face, Findus is not at all a cuddly bear, as he finds closeness very strange. So, extensive cuddles are not Findus's thing, although he does, of course, allow his closest caregivers to rub his belly occasionally. But not from everyone, and only in very small doses. Findus is already used to riding in a car.
Wearing a muzzle is no problem for this proud male, as long as the muzzle is consistently associated with positive things and used in everyday life. He also gets along well with female dogs, especially Rottweiler girls.
For Findus, we are looking for people with extensive experience with dogs, preferably with this breed, who have plenty of patience and time to offer him safe guidance and who can visit him several times at our animal shelter to get to know him. His new home should be in a rural location. He is not suitable for a family with children or as a second dog. Please note that landlord permission is required.
If you would like to give Findus a home, please contact his animal caretakers at the Idefix House at +49 30 76 888 173.

Leila in need – Who will finally give her a chance?
Leila is a special dog who is urgently looking for a home with experience with dogs. She was given to an animal shelter as a puppy and has now unfortunately had to return for the second time. These changing living conditions have not been good for her sensitive soul and are certainly partly the cause of her mistrust and insecurity.
Leila's cheeky nature is merely a defense strategy – she makes a loud noise when she feels insecure. But beneath the facade lies a loyal companion who needs confident and patient people who will encourage and challenge her. With the right guidance and a lot of understanding, Leila can learn to regain trust and feel safe.
A home without other animals would be ideal for Leila, as she needs her owners' full attention. She's a rescue dog who's finally looking for stability and peace to find peace and quiet.

Lilly has a big mouth – but only out of insecurity. She initially tries to chase away anything she doesn't quite trust by barking. If that doesn't work, curiosity gets the better of her, and she slowly begins to approach people, seeing if they might actually be nice. She needs a loving and patient family where she can set the pace to thaw out. Then she'll surely turn into a wonderful little princess. Lilly generally gets along well with other dogs and cats.

Merlin's living conditions in his old home changed so drastically that he could no longer stay there. Therefore, we are looking for a new home for him.
Merlin is friendly towards people and dogs, although a little insecure at first. He loves being outdoors with his owners and exploring the world. At the same time, he also loves to cuddle with his owners. We are looking for people for Merlin who also enjoy exercise and are perhaps familiar with his breed, so that they can actively encourage him and keep him busy. Merlin is not neutered.
