description:
Flo wurde angeboten "wer möchte ihn geschenkt haben". Es war zu turbulent in der Familie und er lernte sich mit Wegschnappen zu wehren. Flo kommt ursprünglich aus Rumänien und nach vielen Recherchen haben wir den ursprünglichen Vermittlungsverein ausfindig gemacht, der aber kein Interesse mehr an dem Hund hatte und ihn nicht wieder zurücknahm.
Flo wird es in der jungen Familie mit den Kindern einfach zu turbulent zugegangen sein und das Einzige, was er machen konnte, um mehr Ruhe zu bekommen, war zuzuschnappen. Leider hat Flo dadurch sein Vertrauen in den Menschen verloren und gelernt, bei allem, was ihm Angst macht, nach vorne zu gehen. Was aber nicht bedeutet, dass Flo nicht vermittelbar ist. Sein Pflegefrauchen kann alles mit ihm machen, dort zeigt er sich als ganz verschmuster, lustiger Kerl.
Flo ist eine Aufgabe, die viel Spaß bringen kann, wenn man Zeit und Geduld hat und sich auf positives Training einlässt. Es ist wunderbar, wenn aus so einem kleinen unsicheren Energiebündel dann ein Hund wird, der sich auf seine Menschen verlassen kann.
UPDATE (Juni 2025): Ein unglaublich süßer Troll, aber er hat seine Macken z.B. mit fremden Leuten, Tierarzt und Fahrradfahrern. Wobei er viele Sachen mitlerweile gut meistert.
shelter_name: Aktiv für Hunde in Not e.V.

description: Jamy has now lost his home twice and is now looking for a PERMANENT HOME who will stick with him through thick and thin and work with him on his problems. Jamy is a dog with a lot of temperament and energy. He knows basic commands, is house trained and gets along well with bitches and neutered males off the leash. However, Jamy has a real problem on the leash when meeting other dogs and is leash aggressive. Here he uses all his physical strength and it is difficult to get him out of this state of excitement. Jamy is familiar with dog training and should continue to attend dog training. So far he has not found a way to cope with his frustration. So he is a dog with areas to work on. This requires understanding, dog experience and perseverance. Jamy will thank you for these three things with his endless love and as a best friend. Due to his breed bond, he has a lot of drive and a willingness to work and learn. Key data: Jamy, German Shepherd/Aussie mix, born October 1, 2019, house-trained, active, good basic obedience (sit, stay, etc.), rides in the car, off-leash, friendly with other dogs (female, neutered), leash-pushing, active

Timba came to us from a rescue. Unfortunately, there have been bite incidents with humans, which is why he must be muzzled and leash-wearing. Timba is very fond of other female dogs and could therefore be adopted as a second dog. Timba also defends resources such as his food or toys.
His new owners should have experience with more difficult dogs and be equally active—he has a lot of energy. Timba would like to move into a home with a fenced yard. Children should not live in the household. To get to know Timba, you should plan several visits to the shelter. Once he gains trust, he is very personable; however, he doesn't like strangers very much.
If you would like to give Timba a home, please send an email with your phone number to tiervermittlung@tierschutz-berlin.de. We look forward to hearing from you.

Once Pino has taken a liking to someone, he'll happily stick with them and is a loyal and gentle companion. Pino is a quiet companion and is unfortunately often overlooked in his search for a good home. He doesn't like hectic surroundings. Crowds, confined spaces, and unfortunately, even children, cause him stress. If you enjoy the tranquility of nature and like a cozy home, then the ideal companion is waiting for you here. With strangers and dogs, Pino initially requests his personal space and is wary of strangers. If you don't pressure him, you've taken the first step toward becoming his friend. Dog-friendly cats are no problem for Pino. Pino rarely goes by car, but he handles it perfectly. Pino also works very well at home alone for up to about four hours. Who recognizes Pino's gentle soul and would like to spend life with him?

Rava came to us as a stray dog and hasn't been missed yet.
Rava is motivated by hunting; small animals/cats and small children should not be in her new home.
When she sees water, no matter what form it takes, Ariel the Little Mermaid also appears.
When we go for a walk, she's currently mutating into a little rocker girl when she meets other dogs.

Thea was rescued and, as a puppy, only knew life in a stable and outside. Thanks to intensive training with our dog trainer, Thea has developed into a wonderful dog with great self-confidence.
Unfortunately, she has developed health problems that will accompany her for the rest of her life. Thea has a head tremor and tends to have a wobbly, uncoordinated gait. As expected, her symptoms worsen when she is excited. An MRI and a cerebrospinal fluid test were unremarkable. Due to her limitations, we would like Thea to be housed on the ground floor. To live a long and as healthy a life as possible, Thea needs continued support in the form of nutritional supplements and physical therapy to build muscle.
We are looking for people for Thea who have experience in dealing with dogs with special needs and strong characters. Thea needs consistent leadership to compensate for her lack of socialization. We therefore recommend that children in the household should already be teenagers.

Cody is a young and spirited TWH male who is outgoing in his familiar home, but initially rather insecure in unfamiliar surroundings.
We are looking for people who have experience with and are familiar with the breed.
The household should be free of cats and small children, and only suitable for children over the age of 15.

Melinda is a Caucasian Shepherd Dog. She came to us with her sister Marina as a foster home from poor conditions.
We worked extensively with Melinda and paired her with canine partners who socialize with people to gain her trust.
For Melinda, we are looking for confident owners who demonstrate clear leadership and a rural environment with a well-fenced property.

Mixed-breed male Bibo, estimated to be about three years old, came to the shelter this summer as a stray. Therefore, nothing can be said about his past. Initially, he spent a few days with his finders. Apparently, no one misses Bibo. In the shelter, the young male gives the impression that he hasn't experienced much in his life yet. Therefore, there is a lot of catching up to do.
It is questionable whether he can be left alone. He acts very excitedly around strangers and barks at them. This initial skepticism eventually subsides. Once Bibo has thawed out, he reveals himself to be an open-minded young dog who enjoys being petted.
Overall, Bibo is rather skeptical of everything new, so he needs to be introduced to many things gradually, such as silent encounters on a leash. He gets along quite well with other dogs, depending on their sympathy. There should be no children in his new home, as this would certainly be overwhelming for everyone involved. Bibo needs people who provide him with security and are willing to work with him.

Our Lino is a real whirlwind! Unfortunately, he can also be boisterous and unruly at times. Basically, our Lino is a really great guy. He's playful, very affectionate and cuddly with people he knows. He's eager to learn and super intelligent with lots of energy. A true sports star with a clever mind. Unfortunately, Lino also has another side. A side characterized by insecurities and a certain hunting instinct. Lino also has a problem with men and strangers. As long as you lead him confidently and make decisions for him, he shows his good side and is very friendly towards people. We would like him to find a home with dog experience. You should be willing and enjoy working with him and having some adventures.

Young Cub came to us as a stray. He's a Malinois mix, a dedicated working dog, and despite his young age, he's already exhibiting problematic behaviors that urgently need to be addressed: He's sensitive to stress and is completely overstimulated in the shelter, making it difficult for him to calm down. At the same time, he's also very sensitive and doesn't tolerate pressure—he tends to engage in displacement behaviors, biting things nearby (including trouser legs, etc.). He also hasn't yet learned to be friendly toward strangers and other dogs. He needs to be handled confidently so he can become more relaxed in new situations. Currently, the mere sight of other people triggers him to attack while on the leash.
Cub is very attentive, docile, and eager to work. He is looking for a home with dedicated people who will keep him meaningfully occupied and busy, and ideally have experience with working dogs. Due to his existing behavioral problems, he is NOT suitable for protection dog sports. However, a calm, focused dog sport would be perfect for him. Mantrailing or Hoopers, for example, are suitable for this. Cub already knows basic commands like sit and stay, but he doesn't yet carry them out with concentration with us. We are working on his leash training, and he also enjoys being taught new things by his owners. In general, he forms a strong bond with "his owners" after the second introduction.
Cub is still young, boisterous, and somewhat boisterous. With the right training and experienced people, he can become a truly good friend and "work colleague." He is not a family dog and unfortunately not suited to living with children. He handles muzzle training well. He is probably only partially suitable as a second dog—but with experienced people and a good getting-to-know-you phase, we can imagine him also moving in with a confident first dog of a suitable age/size/temperament.
Typical for the breed, he is protective of family and property and needs a quieter residential area on the outskirts of town. He is not suited to the bustling city, as he cannot process the many stimuli and reacts with strong displacement behavior. Because his bones are still developing, he shouldn't climb too many stairs.

Oli is a male, vaccinated, and microchipped dachshund-Labrador mix originally from Greece. Oli is a special dog who presents some challenges and is therefore looking for an experienced home.
Description from a dog trainer currently working with Oli:
Oli responds quickly to his caregiver in familiar surroundings. A friendly approach gets him started and he's eager to do something.
Oli has a neutered microchip, but he still marks a lot.

Bonny is a cuddly, stubborn dog and unfortunately still unruly. She is lively, house-trained, knows basic commands, and is looking for a home with experience with this breed.
Bonny doesn't like other dogs or animals at all. Therefore, she is not suited to a life in the city with lots of dog encounters. She wants her "territory" all to herself. Whether she can be left alone is not yet known.
A quieter environment on the outskirts of town or in the countryside would be ideal for Bonny. Children living in the household should be at least 14 years old. Cats should not wait for her. Bonny also has a strong hunting instinct. Please note that due to the breed, Bonny requires a landlord's permit.
If you are interested in Bonny or have any questions about her, please fill out the form below or contact her animal care team by phone at 030 76 888-173.

Muski wants to get started again at 13. Yes, that's right, because age is just a number. Admittedly, three-hour walks shouldn't be allowed anymore, but exploring the countryside for an hour at a time is definitely possible. To satisfy his curiosity, the walks can be kept interesting. He's already experienced a lot in his life. From boat trips and flights to long vacation car rides – a worldly dog! Nevertheless, it's time to give him a consistent environment where he can settle in, where there's room for his needs, and where he's seen as a whole again. There should be no cats or small animals in his new home. Will this handsome guy win your heart too?

Microchipped: No, will be done before adoption
In the shelter since/origin: 08.01.2025/Brieselang
shelter_name: Tierschutzverein Tierheim Falkensee und Umgebung e.V.

description:
Einstein is a young bundle of energy who still has a lot to learn.
He arrived at our animal shelter some time ago, along with his mother and siblings. The family was affectionately known to us as the "polar bear family." Our little heartbreaker was quickly adopted.
Unfortunately, his family had to part with him, which is why the little polar bear is now back at our animal shelter, waiting for his big day.
He is a friendly little fellow who needs a loving but consistent hand. We suspect he's a livestock guardian dog mix, so some dog experience would certainly be an advantage.

I'm Kooper and I'm about five years old.


They couldn't handle us so well there – that's why Britti, the shelter manager, picked us up, because there was even talk of us being presented to an ethics committee.
I'm the tallest of the three of us – but also the cautious one. I'm very skeptical of strangers.

Hey everyone, I'm speaking up now. After being fired from my job as a cleaning lady by the animal shelter staff, I now have to find a new life's work on my own. The cleaning thing really didn't work out. My talents lie more on the emotional side. I love to cuddle and enjoy being petted for hours. After the employees have had their fill of cuddle hormones, I'm happy to move their shoes from the locker room to the kitchen and work on them. Afterward, I romp through the kitchen with my friend Myra, before giving Vilko and Bobina a piece of my mind through the fence. I'm sure you'll agree with me that I absolutely have to get out of here. At my young age (1.5 years old), I want to see more of the world than just here at the animal shelter. Besides, I'm sure my skills can still be improved. I have to admit, I look taller in the photos than I actually am. My shoulder height is max. 40 cm

We adopted Molly, along with Flip and Marie, from one of our member associations. They originally came from an animal hoarding case.
Since Molly is unfamiliar with a leash, collar, or harness, she has to learn the ropes from scratch. For this sensitive dog, we are looking for people with experience with dogs who are patient, calm, and empathetic. Ideally, someone with experience with working dog breeds would be a valuable addition to Molly's new home, providing her with security and serving as a role model.
The adoption process for one of our dogs typically proceeds as follows:
shelter_name: Sonnenhof für Mensch und Tier, eine Einrichtung vom Deutschen Tierschutzbund e.V.

description:
Der Mischlingsrüde Willi landete ursprünglich im Tierheim, weil er mit den vielen Enkelkindern in der Familie überfordert war. Wir haben ihn von einem unserer Mitgliedsvereine übernommen. Willi hatte bereits kurzzeitig ein neues Zuhause, wo es schlussendlich leider nicht funktioniert hat.
In der Vergangenheit gab es bei Willi gelegentlich Probleme, wenn Besucher sein zuhause betreten haben. Dies lässt sich hervorragend durch Management umgehen. Willi ist das Tragen eines Maulkorbes prinzipiell gewohnt, dies muss aber in seinem neuen Zuhause weiterhin trainiert werden. Für Willi suchen wir Personen, die seine teilweise sehr kleinen Signale lesen und akzeptieren können und ihn in schwierigen Situationen unterstützen und ihm Sicherheit geben.
Aufgrund seiner Vorgeschichte wird er nur in einen kinderlosen Haushalt mit hundeerfahrenen Menschen vermittelt. Bei Problemen stehen wir Willis neuer Familie jederzeit mit professioneller Hilfe zur Seite.
Die Vermittlung einer unserer Hunde läuft in der Regel wie folgt ab:
shelter_name: Sonnenhof für Mensch und Tier, eine Einrichtung vom Deutschen Tierschutzbund e.V.

description:
Cody is currently housed in a boarding facility and is receiving a lot of training there: In the dog group, he is social when his owner can give him the appropriate guidance on how to behave with new friends. However, in a domestic setting, he is still a challenge and requires a lot of forward-looking management. He is currently in North Rhine-Westphalia and must be visited there as well. Please contact us if you are interested in Cody.
Cody was surrendered to the animal shelter because his previous owners were overwhelmed. He has bitten people several times, even within his own family. Despite his small size, Cody is a difficult dog, and we will only place him in experienced hands. He defends resources such as food and toys, which is why imitation hunting games are taboo for him. Visits to the vet are an absolute abomination for Cody and are only possible with a muzzle, which he has now associated with positive things and wears very reliably. He has elevated liver values, but is well controlled with medication and currently has no further problems. He will receive free liver treatment at our veterinary practice for life.
This little male is very personable and generally affectionate with people he knows. However, he doesn't like being touched on his back, in the lumbar region, or on his tail—he will then attack without warning. Some malformed vertebrae in his spine suggest that touching this area hurts him.
Cody walks well on a leash and can be led past anyone and everything on walks without any problem. Other dogs are perfectly fine, depending on how well they get along—you don't have to like everyone, but if there's a good enough affinity, we would also be happy to find him a second dog, for example, to a confident and well-socialized female dog. In his previous home, he lived with a Staffie and even cats.

Hey, I'm Mina! 
I'm friendly, curious, and playful, but with other dogs, I decide who's allowed into my circle of friends—liking is everything!
If you're ready to make every day exciting with me, then let's get to know each other – I promise, it'll never be boring with me!
Here's a short video of me: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/RGrPY6DZM4w

breed: Border Collie - Cocker Spaniel - Schäferhund - Golden Retriever Mix
description:
Born: April 28, 2022
Shoulder height: 49cm
Our beautiful Buddy is a very affectionate, people-oriented, intelligent, and cuddly dog. Since he didn't receive the necessary consistency and training from an early age, he is overwhelmed in many situations and absolutely needs security and clear instructions about what to do in any situation and how to behave. If he believes you aren't strong enough to lead the pack, he (and his owners) will try to discipline him. Ideally, we would find people for Buddy who are motivated to work with him and, above all, to stimulate him mentally, for example, through search training, agility, dog dancing, etc. Buddy has no problems with other dogs and has shown himself submissive so far. He would be very suitable as a second dog; of course, compatibility will be tested individually.

Socke was brought to us with the information that he had been found tied up in the woods somewhere about 10 kilometers from the animal shelter. Unfortunately, we couldn't find an owner or any information about his life so far.
We've named the poor but cool Socke "Socke" accordingly and estimate him to be about two to three years old.
Typical German Shepherd, he needs a moment to warm up to new people and situations, but once he's done, he's very affectionate. As an open-minded, but still somewhat insecure dog, he seeks guidance from humans and should – typical of the breed – be given clear structures and rules so that he doesn't become overwhelmed by insecurities or ambiguities.
Socke is cuddly, somewhat uncouth, and enjoys tasks and activities.

Bobby is actually a dream dog - just not with strangers...
Our animal shelter isn't the first place Bobby has had to live. And that's probably where his insecurity comes from.
He's a dog who, out of fear, tends to move forward rather than back, and that's why a home with experience with dogs is essential for him.
In his interactions with our animal keepers, Bobby is uncomplicated, extremely friendly, and even cuddly. He also enjoys going for walks and generally gets along well with other dogs.

James, an Ovcharka mix, was born around the beginning of 2022 and is currently unneutered.


James therefore enjoys the opportunity to spend time outdoors, but also with his owner.

Django - a truly cuddly, cuddly little fellow to adore. This friendly male was surrendered to us due to illness and is now looking for his dream family with the appropriate certificate of competence. He is a very sweet guy with a big heart. He already knows some basic commands and can even be left alone for a few hours. He's also a real water rat! In the summer, he swims laps in the "dog pool" for hours and then relaxes completely exhausted in the evening. Due to his weight, he has a lot of strength, which is why we are looking for a home with experience with dogs. Only as an only dog, as he doesn't accept other dogs besides his owner. Django weighs 46 kg and is 57 cm tall.

Young Luce happily accompanies her caregivers and curiously explores her surroundings on walks.
Luce is a livestock guardian dog mix, and with these dogs, the behavior of an adult dog develops gradually and much more slowly than with smaller dogs. This means that Luce will remain a "child" for quite some time.
Her future owners should be prepared for a certain amount of watchfulness—this is completely normal for livestock guardian dogs.

Ork was seized by the veterinary office along with two other dogs and is now waiting at the animal shelter for experienced dog owners. He is very alert and initially very suspicious and tense around strangers. But behind this skepticism lies a loyal dog who is just waiting to gain someone's trust.
Ork doesn't like being left alone yet and likes to pull on the leash, which still needs some work. Despite these small hurdles, Ork has good basic obedience.
Our dogs are dewormed, vaccinated, and microchipped.

We adopted Flip, along with Molly and Marie, from one of our member associations. They originally came from an animal hoarding case.
Since Flip isn't used to a leash, collar, or harness, he has to learn the ropes from scratch. For his further development, he is looking for people with experience with dogs, ideally with experience with working dog breeds. With patience, calmness, and loving consistency, Flip will gain confidence step by step and grow into a loyal companion.
We would like Flip to have a sensitive home where he will have the time and support he needs to gain trust, and with people who want to explore the world with him.
At least three visits to Sonnenhof are planned. These visits are important to us, as this is the time you can get to know your potential foster, and he can get to know you. Before the dog can finally move in with you, we will conduct a preliminary inspection at your home.
shelter_name: Sonnenhof für Mensch und Tier, eine Einrichtung vom Deutschen Tierschutzbund e.V.

Short & Crisp
born on June 1, 2021
approximately 60 cm
house-trained

SOS Forgotten Paws e.V.
Hello everyone, I'm Moritz, a handsome male dog – born in June 2022 – and at 52 cm tall, already fully grown. I'm an active, playful, and cuddly companion who loves life and wants to stick by my human through thick and thin. I'm looking for a loving forever home – a place where I can arrive, find security, and where my humans will guide me through life with heart, patience, and clear leadership. Ideally with you!!! My human and our behavior trainer, Lili. Depending on compatibility, I also get along with other dogs. Children, cats, and other small animals shouldn't be in my home. I would be ideally suited to a couple or a single person with several years of experience with dogs. I'm currently in the typical "rebellious" phase – right in the middle of that exciting time where I'm testing my limits. Therefore, I wish for a person who will take on the role of pack leader: someone who will show me, with loving consistency, clarity, and patience, what is allowed – and what isn't. I need structure, security, and someone I can look to for guidance. Then I will quickly grow into a reliable and well-balanced companion. My basic commands aren't perfect yet, but I am intelligent, attentive, and eager to learn. I am being rehomed through the animal welfare organization SOS Vergessene Pfoten Tierschutz e.V. (SOS Forgotten Paws Animal Welfare) with a protection contract and for a rehoming fee of €550. I am, of course, vaccinated, microchipped, dewormed, neutered, and already registered with Tasso. You can purchase a suitable safety harness, a regular harness, a collar, and a leash (all in good condition) for me from our organization. This starter kit ensures that I feel safe, secure, and well cared for from the very beginning. Do you have a place in your heart and on your sofa? Then don't wait any longer. I'm looking forward to meeting you. We would be delighted if you followed us in the Facebook group, on Instagram, and on TikTok. There you'll get lots of insights into our work, the association, and of course, our furry friends. Animal Encounters on Saturday, November 1st. Moritz can be visited in Hagen on Monday, November 2nd, 2025 from 2:00 PM to 5:00 PM and on Sunday, November 2nd, 2025 from 3:00 PM to 5:00 PM at Alter Henkhauser Weg 58 in 58119 Hagen. We look forward to your visit!!
Moritz can be visited in Hagen!!
Tel.: 0160/96925678

New Year – New Luck for Male Dog Mio
Neutered male Mio is a Border Collie, German Shepherd, and Labrador mix, and a real unlucky dog. Not only is he black, which unfortunately still leaves him with a poor chance of being adopted, but he's also mostly experienced the downsides of his life so far. He's now 8 years old, and has spent 7 of those years in poor conditions, including 1 year in an animal shelter.
Mio came to us at the animal shelter in poor nutritional condition. He previously lived on a property with 7 dogs and learned what hunger means. This left its mark on him, and he can develop food aggression toward other dogs. And there's another thing Mio doesn't like at all. Loud men and the smell of alcohol. This, too, has something to do with his previous behavior.
It's all the more surprising that Mio is a really happy dog. Every morning, he's overjoyed to see us and go outside. He loves going for walks, loves water, puddles, digging, and rolling in the grass. He's curious and behaves like a young dog.
shelter_name: Tierschutzverein Isenhagener Land im Landkreis Gifhorn e. V.

description:
Ares came to us because his owners were overwhelmed. He was originally found abandoned in the woods as a puppy in 2019. According to the previous owner, the handsome dog had a history of biting. With us, he's a friendly and very peaceful four-legged friend, but he shouldn't be underestimated or handled carelessly. He's also said to vigorously defend his food. To break this kind of behavior, we need animal lovers with experience with dogs, ideally with the breed, who can approach Ares with consistency and patience. Children should not live in the household. Ares is already quite capable: He's house-trained and used to riding in a car. He's also an athletic and alert dog who looks forward to many active hours with the right people.
Due to his sometimes unusual behavior, Ares' adoption is supported by our dog trainer. Several visits to our shelter are necessary so that prospective adopters and our shelter pet can get to know each other in his familiar surroundings. After adoption, attendance at a suitable dog (owner) school is essential. Our animal caretakers will be happy to advise you.
Ares had a special castration procedure, during which both his testicle and his uterus were removed. His animal caretakers will be happy to answer any questions you may have. Otherwise, this handsome dog is very fit and alert.
Please note that Ares is one of the so-called listed dogs, meaning his ownership is prohibited in Brandenburg and is subject to proof of competence in Berlin. Furthermore, muzzles and leashes are mandatory in Berlin.

We adopted Pauline, a mixed-breed dog, along with her six puppies from one of our member associations. They originally came from an animal hoarding case.
To best prepare Pauline for life in her new home, we are currently working on getting her used to a collar, harness, and leash.
For Pauline, we are looking for patient people who will stick with her through thick and thin and show her the good things in life. With a little sensitivity and training, Pauline will become a truly loyal companion.
The placement of one of our dogs usually proceeds as follows:
shelter_name: Sonnenhof für Mensch und Tier, eine Einrichtung vom Deutschen Tierschutzbund e.V.

description:
Power Pill—that's probably the best name for our little mouse. When Pille is around, you can tell, because she's a real cheerleader. She's not so fond of other dogs, but depending on how well they like her, she can get along with them.
Despite her medium size, Pille has a lot of strength and definitely needs to be trained, especially when walking on a leash. She's definitely not a couch potato and wants to experience a lot. Dog sports would certainly be interesting for her.
People with experience with herding dogs would be a great fit for Pille, because this opinionated little mouse is not for beginners. We're currently practicing reliably wearing a muzzle with her when we go for walks.
Children and cats/small animals should not live in the household.

description:
Jacky was given to us because of a move. Unfortunately, despite long conversations and explicit questions, the previous owners didn't tell us everything about the little guy, so we're left with speculation as to whether it was solely the move.
Jacky is actually a great little guy. He loves going for walks, loves to cuddle, and enjoys being with people. However, he doesn't like having his harness removed; he bites at the leash, harness, and hands.

description:
Lia is a sensitive, approximately 2.5-year-old, spayed female dog with a shaggy look, perhaps an Irish Wolfhound mix? Lia is about 65 cm tall, so friends of large dogs are needed.
Lia is still a bit shy around people, but she is happy to be bribed with treats.
We are looking for a quiet home for our gentle giant with loving and patient two-legged friends who will show her how wonderful life is as a real family member.
Lia loves to lie outside. Our dream would therefore be a home with a well-fenced garden, where she can decide for herself whether to stay outside or come inside. Small children and small pets should not be present in the new home.

Fina had already been adopted, but she returned after 6 months because she was able to successfully take over in her new home! Fina is NOT a dog for beginners! If not guided consistently, Fina likes to take matters into her own hands and manage resources and space. The princess status often associated with this breed is poison for Finchen and goes to her head. Without a stable companion, she quickly becomes a terror queen who rules her family on her terms. She needs clear body language and rules. She sees purely positive training methods based on positive conditioning and treats as a weakness and will question them after a short time. Here with us, she works well in the dog group. However, it must also be clear that the human is leading the group. Once she has found her place and knows that she is not under the control of the owner, she is a cuddly, friendly dog who enjoys walks, can be left alone, and also rides well in the car. Unfortunately, she has developed an allergy and is given a tablet twice a day. This means she is symptom-free. She also has bilateral keratoconjunctivitis sicca, meaning she doesn't produce tears, which, if left untreated, leads to painful irritation and itching. Therefore, she needs to apply eye ointment several times a day, which she tolerates well. Fina is neutered. Cats and small animals should not live in her new home. She will also not be rehomed with children. She wears a muzzle without any problems, which she will continue to need in certain situations (e.g., at the vet).

Lotte is possibly a purebred German Pinscher. This shy female dog was born around 2022 and is not yet spayed.
Unfortunately, they hadn't been exposed to anything in their previous home and therefore need patience, sensitivity, and love in their new home.
Therefore, a garden with a dog-proof fence is also required.

Sparky is an active dog who loves walks in nature, especially in water.
He's not a cuddly bear, but he would still be very happy in a familiar home.

Hey, I'm Mina! 
I'm friendly, curious, and playful, but with other dogs, I decide who's allowed into my circle of friends—sympathy is everything!
If you're ready to make every day exciting with me, then let's get to know each other – I promise, it'll never be boring with me!
Here's a short video of me: https://www.youtube.com/shorts/RGrPY6DZM4w

Noran is a very self-confident TWH male who clearly states his position regarding other dogs. Therefore, we see Noran as a prince of one, where he doesn't always have to take charge. He is initially somewhat skeptical of strangers, but with plenty of time and patience, you can gain his trust.
Noran would like a home in a rural area with a house and land. It should have a fence at least 2 meters high with anti-digging and anti-climbing protection and no dogs living in the household.
Noran is very good on a leash and knows basic commands.

Barny was surrendered because he was dominating the family's second dog, a Maltese. Barny repeatedly displayed aggressive behavior toward his owners. He used threatening language but never bit. His former owners suspect that Barny came from an illegal puppy trade. They later noticed some inconsistencies in the adoption process. Barny's behavior toward dogs was strange from puppyhood onward. He either behaves like a super-pushy puppy or he bullies the others and simply won't leave them alone. Resource guarding toward people and dogs also plays a role in his behavior. In his foster home, his behavior fluctuates between trusting and cuddly and suspicious and tense. Barny should be an only dog in a home without children or pets. Barny is a very handsome miniature bull terrier. He needs people who love him and can handle his sometimes strange behavior. He enjoys going for walks. He enjoys many kinds of activities and treat hunting, and he loves his chewing fun.

Male Ben
Age: Born May 2022
Gender: Male/ neutered
We adopted Ben from a foster home run by an animal welfare organization because he displayed behavioral issues there that made living with others difficult.

Ed came to us a year ago with other dogs from a disastrous situation. Unfortunately, he didn't know much and had a lot of catching up to do with the basics of being a small dog, including housetraining, walking on a leash, and generally how to behave in a normal household. Some shortcomings, such as housetraining and walking on a leash, have improved since then, but dog encounters still need to be trained.
Ed is a very active dog and would appreciate a jogging partner. He is initially skeptical of strangers, but then very happy to be given affection. He is also somewhat compatible with other dogs, but rather questionable with cats and small animals. Children should be older. Ed would be suitable for those with dog experience, but also for beginners who would like to learn with him in dog training. A house or apartment with a garden in a somewhat quieter location would be ideal for boisterous Ed.

We adopted this wonderful dog, Malo, from another animal welfare organization to give him a better chance of finding his own home. Unfortunately, we can't say much about his past. However, he immediately enchanted us with his amber eyes.
This lovable male is very open and friendly towards people he knows. He particularly enjoys long walks and loves learning tricks. Malo has also already shown quite a bit of training: he not only knows the most common basic commands but also carries them out extremely reliably. He can also travel in the car without any problems and is already used to a home environment.
There are situations, especially in the home, in which Malo shows when he doesn't want something. Unfortunately, this has already involved using his teeth.

Hello, I'm Diva
... a lively, people-oriented dog with a radiant, wonderful personality. Unfortunately, not everything in my life has been going so well so far - that's why I need a reliable, secure leader who offers me clear structures and helps me show my best side. I'm motivated, want to learn, and explore the world together with my human.
Would you like to know more about me?
I really like ...  my people. I hope that they give me the security that I've been missing in my life so far. It would be so nice if someone would love me again.

In Romania, his days were numbered. Emaciated with a torn leg and ill, his chances of survival were close to zero.
Today, Mika is a proud, strong male who has regained his trust in people. He bears his handicap with composure and still darts quickly across the meadows. His coat is now snow-white, and he enjoys excellent health. Mika likes people, enjoys being petted, and is completely house-trained and clean. He has a gentle nature and gratefully accepts any kind of comfort.
He enjoys going for walks; being three-legged means he moves quickly, which is why he pulls a little on the leash. He finds cyclists exciting, so you have to keep an eye on him, and he likes to greet people coming towards him.
Mika is alert; a fenced yard would be an advantage. Visitors are not a problem, but strangers behind the fence will be barked at. Mika is generally friendly with other dogs, but sometimes reacts jealously. So he could definitely become an only dog.

Hello, I'm Paul
… my animal keepers also call me Pauli-Krauli because I love nothing more than cuddling and snuggling.
At the same time, they also say that I'm a scaredy-cat. Unfortunately, they're right, because I really am afraid quite often. Especially of pain. For example, at the vet. I get a muzzle there so that I don't accidentally bite someone, which I don't want to do. But sometimes I'm so scared I just don't know what I'm doing. Luckily, my animal keepers help me and practice with me. The other day, they said they're very proud of me. I've made great progress – and with the right people in the right home, I would become a really "cool sod."
Would you like to know more about me?

Simba was surrendered to us and is now looking for a suitable home. Unfortunately, he hasn't had good experiences in the past, and there have even been biting incidents in his environment. Simba is very suspicious of strangers and needs time to build trust. Structure and a clear line are therefore very important to him. Once he has gained trust, he enjoys contact with his caregivers.
He wears a muzzle and copes very well with it. He still needs some training on a leash, as he needs to be very closely controlled, especially when meeting other dogs.
Due to his history, Simba will only be rehomed to people with experience with dogs, preferably with the breed, who are familiar with difficult dogs. What Simba needs is security and support through friendly but consistent handling and rules he can understand. For his new home, we would like a place in a rural setting with plenty of space to run around, and also without children or other animals in the household.
If you are interested in Simba or have any questions, please contact his animal caretakers at Benji House at +49 30 76 888-212. We look forward to hearing from you!

Gisla and Justin are currently living in a foster home, where they can get to know life alongside people in peace and quiet. Every day they learn new things and enjoy being petted.
Initially, it was planned to rehome the two separately. But they make such a good team and are now inseparable. Even though rehoming makes it a bit more difficult, the two young dogs are looking for a home together.
The two already enjoy going for walks. Gisla is a bit braver and more curious than Justin. In some situations, he still reacts a little uncertainly to environmental stimuli, but he can orient himself well with his sister and his foster mom, so that he can handle these situations well. In the apartment, however, Justin is just as carefree as Gisla, and there they play and rest together extensively.
Even though the two siblings will remain small, they need mental stimulation in addition to physical activity and are already looking forward to engaging in activities.

Breed: German Shepherd
Shoulder height: approx. 65 cm/ 40 kg


Description follows

Aldrin is an imposing figure, but a real bundle of joy at around 50 kg. As a puppy, he was probably hit by a car in a parking lot in Albania. Since then, he has had a slight walking disability and is missing a few toes on one hind foot. He underwent cruciate ligament surgery in Austria, and everything has healed well. In any case, he's happily romping through the meadows here. He has a sweet, sunny disposition, and with that, he's won the hearts of the people here. He spent the last year in Austria with a family that had another dog, a small child, and other animals. The family was very sad that they couldn't keep Aldrin, but their circumstances have changed. We would like to find a home for Aldrin with a fenced yard where he can continue his herd protection duties. We're looking for people who might be comfortable with the dog not wanting to go for walks for two to three hours a day, who can allow him freedom outside, but still offer a close family connection in the house. Depending on the dog's affinity, Aldrin can also be placed with another dog. Aldrin takes his livestock guardianship duties seriously, but he enjoys being guided and even directed. Simply letting him run around and make his own decisions can sometimes lead in the wrong direction. Therefore, we're looking for people with livestock guardian dog experience—or people who are familiar with the process and who can and are willing to maintain a clear line. So, back to the topic of children: family members are loved and sometimes protected. When unfamiliar children come to visit, things can get a bit louder, rougher, and more hectic. When Aldrin tries to sort through what he sees as chaos, it could lead to misunderstandings—and that's not what you want. Therefore, forward-looking management is required that doesn't cause stress for either the dog or the humans. Aldrin needs time to adjust to new situations. It would be nice if his new owners could get to know Aldrin through a few visits, so that some trust is established on both sides before he moves in. He settled in quite quickly at the shelter and actually really liked the people here. We hope that he will soon become a happy dog in his new home, with his people, house, and property.

I look like a polar bear, and I can be just as independent and stubborn. As long as no one sets boundaries and rules for me, I do what I want. I'm happy to look after you, but I also make sure no one steps out of line. While I've been told that you humans don't like it when you restrict you, this way I feel like I have everything under control. But if someone shows me that I don't have to control anything because you do it for me, I'll gladly accept the offer. I think my humans are great and enjoy their attention and cuddles. However, I don't like being constrained; that can sometimes make me angry. My humans are protected by me, and I look after them. Therefore, I need a confident person who can sometimes take the wind out of my sails. I dream of having my own basket with someone who knows how to handle me and guides me confidently through life. ... And while we're talking about my perfect home, I see myself in a rural house with a garden that I can look after from time to time. People who have experience with dogs and can understand me. Preferably in a childless household. Other dogs aren't always my cup of tea, and I'd like a home where I can be the only one.

The shy Motte was born around 2022 and has not yet been neutered. Motte is likely a German Pinscher-Ridgeback mix.
Unfortunately, they hadn't been exposed to anything in their previous home and therefore need patience, sensitivity, and love in their new home.
Therefore, a garden with a dog-proof fence is also required.

Balu came to a family with no experience with dogs as a young puppy, and he may never have known proper boundaries or his owners as competent partners. Unfortunately, he eventually snapped when he felt threatened. It seems that he doesn't feel comfortable in small spaces and becomes insecure when he does. With us, he now walks well on a leash and calmly lets other dogs pass him – unless they bully him too much. Balu gets along well with female dogs, but is a bit boisterous when meeting new ones. If there's a good rapport, he could also be rehomed with a stable female dog.
We're looking for people with experience with dogs for Balu who can provide him with a great home and the necessary structure. He needs someone who will give him clear and confident leadership and set fair boundaries. Children should not live in the household. Balu is not at all comfortable with being touched on his head or paws. He's used to wearing a muzzle. Due to Balu's insecurity, please plan several visits to get to know him and build trust.
If you would like to give Balu the right home or have any questions, please contact his animal caretakers at Lassie House by phone at +49 30 76 888-220. We look forward to hearing from you!

Milo's past has been very low-stimulation. Acquired as a puppy, he quickly lost interest, and he remained on the farm. Getting to know the world and the various environmental stimuli associated with it – no chance. When he bit a family member one day, he was sent to the animal shelter.
Generally, Milo's frustration tolerance is very low, meaning that even the smallest triggers are enough to quickly overwhelm him, trigger frustration, and result in (redirected) aggression. The triggers are very different, e.g. the treat is not pushed through the muzzle quickly enough, strange dogs, sometimes even when several people he knows are in the room. Due to his problem behavior, he will not be rehomed in a family with children. Experienced dog owners are needed here, who ideally have already gained experience with this type of problem behavior. Clear rules and boundaries are essential for Milo, and the new two-legged friend must be able to offer him secure leadership and continue to work on his problems. If he knows his people and trusts them, he will be a loyal companion.
Even though Milo has a low frustration tolerance, he does well in training if there are no distractions. "Sit," "down," and "stay" work wonderfully, but he still needs more practice walking properly on a leash, for example. He really enjoys playing foraging games. His leash aggression and resource guarding also need further work.
Milo is neutered, de-fleaed, de-wormed, vaccinated, and microchipped.

The cute Cassy with her sweet floppy ears enchants everyone at first sight. Cassy comes from our Romanian partner animal shelter and unfortunately hasn't had the chance to experience much in her life. Therefore, Cassy is still quite unsure of herself around people and is looking for new owners who have experience with anxious dogs. She already walks very well on a leash and loves long walks. She would like a home with a house and property in a quiet rural area. Cassy would greatly benefit from an existing, confident first dog who can provide her with security. There should be no small children in the household.
Getting to know Cassy should include several visits. Getting used to her new home will also take a lot of time. You should be aware of the challenges of having an anxious dog and approach this experience with plenty of patience.

Racoon was found and, unfortunately, due to his breed, has been waiting a long time for a new home. There are dogs who cope much worse with life in animal shelters than others – Racoon is one of them. In the shelter, he is very restless, temperamental, and unfriendly. He is still young and wants to get out into the world and experience something with a human being who is all his own. He lacks all of that and understandably causes pent-up frustration that needs to be released somewhere. After a walk and when you take some time for him, he quickly becomes much more relaxed. We have often seen dogs like Racoon completely change in their own right and mutate into relaxed couch potatoes – who will give him a chance?
Racoon is looking for confident people with experience with dogs who can give him clear guidance, encourage him, and devote plenty of time to him. The support of a suitable dog school would certainly be beneficial. Please note that due to his breed, Racoon is subject to a muzzle and leash requirement, and landlord approval is required for his ownership. Children should not live in the household.
Who would like to give Racoon a wonderful life and help him regain his contentment and balance? Please contact his animal caretakers at Struppi-Haus (phone +49 30 76 888 156).

Hello, I'm Max!
I was allowed to move out once before - unfortunately, I had to come back because the family didn't have enough time for me.
Because I have a strong prey drive, I unfortunately can't live with small pets.
Now I'm looking for a home that's truly right for me: loving, consistent, and with enough time for my temperament and needs. Please remember to fill out a self-disclosure form in advance so that I don't become a "wandering trophy" but can finally find the right match.

Vasco – A special dog seeking special people
Vasco has been waiting for a home in the animal shelter for over four years. Born in 2015, the Irish Terrier longs for nothing more than to finally find his place – with people who truly understand him.
But Vasco is not just a "problem dog." He is a dog with great potential – eager to learn, attentive, and genuinely enjoys working with people. He truly thrives on clicker training! He knows basic commands well and walks calmly on a leash – as long as there are no strong distractions like cars or bicycles rushing by.
Those who treat Vasco with patience and clarity will get a loyal, sensitive dog who bonds closely with his caregiver. He's ready – but are you?

Irma, called Irmi, originally comes from Romania. She has been living with us at the shelter for over a year now. Irmi loves all of our staff and she adores other dogs. She loves to play and could cuddle and snuggle with us all day long. She enjoys going out with Tine and long walks. She is happy to be accompanied by Yuma. She is actually a completely normal and happy dog who would fit into any nice family – but unfortunately, that is not the case. Irmi has a hard time adjusting to new things. It takes her a long time to get used to strangers in an environment other than the shelter. She finds cyclists annoying and children very scary. For Irmi, we are looking for people with experience with dogs and a confident first-time dog who can support Irmi in her everyday life. Irmi cannot be rehomed in the city; a home in the countryside in a quiet environment would be ideal. With the right support, Irmi will surely become a wonderful, affectionate, and loyal companion. Irmi is now about 4 years old. Even at this age, it is possible to prepare a dog for life outside of the shelter. If you are interested, please feel free to arrange a meeting by email at buero@tierheim-tuttlingen.de.

The 4-year-old neutered Giant Schnauzer male Barney is confused.
As a young dog, he lived in a committed relationship with his owner. It was just the two of them, and it worked perfectly. Now life has changed for Barney. A small child, another adult, and new four-legged friends are simply too much change for this giant.
Barney is reserved and even suspicious of strangers and doesn't let everyone touch him. Outside, he avoids people.
He gets along well with other dogs. Sometimes pushy and not very sensitive when interacting with others.

Baghira originally came from a foster home and, after more than two years of adoption, unfortunately returned to us. The excessive demands and additional health problems were too much for the owners to handle and financially sustainable.
This handsome mixed breed is still a very active, strong, and spirited dog. He doesn't mean any harm, of course, but he tests whether people are serious about what they want from him and can sometimes be a bit rude and distant. He also needs a little more time to build a deep bond. However, with clear guidance, this intelligent male is a great, reliable partner, but not suitable for beginners. Attending dog training with him is recommended.
Baghira continues to bring great joy to his walker, whom he has known for years, and is making good progress. Motivated, he follows basic commands and shows great progress with his volunteer walker, walking well on a leash and learning. He really enjoys playing forage games—he comes alive when challenged and likes to show off his skills. He also enjoys bathing, and he's usually friendly with other dogs. Once he's settled in, being left alone for hours at a time will need to be practiced consistently—he barked frequently with his previous owner. He generally tends to bark when overwhelmed.
Baghira has pancreatic insufficiency, but is currently coping very well with it. In our practice, he receives free medication and ongoing treatment for life.

I come from another TSV (German Shepherd Club) and am new to the Ruhr area. I'm currently still in the getting-to-know-you and training phase, but my new fosters are already looking for a new home. Due to a negative experience in my youth, I have a hard time with other dogs. On good days, I usually manage to avoid stress. On bad days, however, I can't control myself and really let loose like a leash Rambo. I know and wear the muzzle very well and am easy to handle in many situations. In other situations, I display strong stress behavior and sometimes even tend to engage in displacement behavior. I'm a dog who needs clear structures and rules, because only under such circumstances am I as gentle as butter and actually want to please my owners. I'm looking for people with experience with dogs, especially with breeds, who enjoy taking on challenges and have a lot of self-confidence and patience to guide me in the right direction. My caregivers are sure it will be worth it. Applicants should be prepared to schedule multiple appointments.

Cora and Muriel, two Husky-Maremmano mixes, are looking for a loving home. They were born on November 14, 2017. Cora and Muriel are a Husky-Maremmano mix, making them unique and beautiful dogs. They have a soft and thick coat that's well-suited to cold weather. They are very intelligent, playful, and active. They both love running around outside and exploring new things. They need plenty of exercise and mental challenges to be happy and well-adjusted. Both are vaccinated and neutered. We are looking for a home for them where they will receive plenty of love, time, and attention. Ideally, their new home should have a fenced yard or garden where they can move freely. Both require consistent but loving training and individualized activities to meet their mental and physical needs. They can't be left alone and are very attached to each other, so individual adoption is out of the question. If you are interested in offering these two a loving home, please contact us at 02528-3630 to learn more about them and to arrange a meeting.

Claire has been found. She is very lively and self-confident, needs clear leadership and a purpose, structure, and authority – she doesn't seem to have experienced this from her previous home.
Claire is calmly led past other dogs and knows basic commands. She is house-trained and personable. She defends food and toys; imitation hunting games are not suitable for her. Overall, she is very alert. Because she has hip problems, her future home should be on the ground floor. She is given pain medication, which she takes without any problems. She will receive lifelong, free treatment for her hip dysplasia at our animal shelter.
We are looking for a home for Claire with people who are experienced with the breed and who are familiar with more demanding dogs, in a quiet environment with a fenced yard. Children should not live in the household. To get to know Claire, several visits to the animal shelter will be necessary – The placement will be supervised by our dog trainer.
If you can offer Claire what she so desperately needs, please contact her animal caretakers at Benji House at 030 76 888-212 if you are interested or have any questions.

Blue came to us after being confiscated for violating animal protection laws. Unfortunately, he has a history of biting people. This powerful male dog is very distrustful of strangers. He is easily hand-fed by his caregivers, which motivates him. Other dogs still quickly overwhelm him, but he has now learned to walk calmly in a group of dogs. The only important thing is that he walks in front of the other dogs. He wears his muzzle well; he has associated it with positive feelings. Blue is undergoing behavioral therapy with us and is making good progress. He particularly enjoys the therapy sessions on the water treadmill—and since he already has some minor orthopedic problems with his musculoskeletal system, regular gentle exercise in the water is particularly beneficial for him.
Otherwise, Blue is more of a "couch potato" type—he likes it warm and cozy. He is prone to obesity, so his new owners will have to keep an eye on this. Due to his musculoskeletal problems, he shouldn't be overweight.
Blue is only suitable for very experienced Staffie owners who already have experience with dogs that have bitten people. New owners must be able and willing to work with him accordingly. Children and other animals should not live in the household. Blue is also not at all suitable for the inner city; a home in the countryside or at most on the outskirts of town would be ideal. We also recommend regular attendance at a good dog training school. Interested parties should be able to visit Blue several times at the animal shelter so he can get used to them and gain trust. Due to his breed and history, landlord permission is required in many places, and he must be muzzled and kept on a leash in public.
If you would like to give Blue the right home or have any questions, please contact us at tiervermittlung@tierschutz-berlin.de, describing your living circumstances and previous dog experience, along with a meaningful email address and a callback number, or carefully fill out the form below. You are also welcome to call us. Please contact his animal caretakers at the Reha-Haus at +49 30 76 888-204. We look forward to hearing from you!

A little rescue!
Schelly is about 2 years old, spayed, and approximately 40 cm tall. Unfortunately, Schelly hasn't had a very good life so far. She's still a bit reserved, but she's slowly gaining confidence and becoming more outgoing. This mixed-breed dog also has an old injury-related hip problem, which currently only minimally affects her gait. The shelter will cover the treatment costs for this pre-existing condition for the rest of her life (pain medication or even surgery may be necessary later).
Schelly shouldn't be physically overexerted. We're therefore looking for a quiet home for her, preferably on the ground floor or with an elevator. Rough play with other dogs or children would not be suitable. Instead, Schelly needs mental stimulation, as she's still quite a young dog. She currently has a short haircut.
Please contact the animal shelter by phone if you are interested in showing Schelly the wonderful sides of life: Tel. 02333 – 72068.

Senior Brandon has unfortunately been living with us at the animal shelter for quite some time now. Nevertheless, we're not giving up hope of finding a forever home for him too.
The beginnings with Brandon were anything but easy. In the first few months, he barked at everything he came across on walks: other dogs, cyclists, horses, joggers, etc.


Brandon can easily run with a group of dogs and is otherwise friendly with other dogs – although he can happily do without other male dogs in his bedroom.

I am a large, young, black German Shepherd mix, full of energy and zest for life. I've already learned a lot at the animal shelter, know basic commands, usually walk well on a leash, and want to please. Above all, I want to belong. I get along well with other dogs, but I don't really like cats. Environmental influences and moving stimuli still stress me, but I'm working on tolerating them. I'm looking for people with experience, patience, and a relatively quiet home.

Rulis, a 14-month-old mixed-breed livestock guardian dog, is looking for a loving, lifelong home. Rulis is a very playful, well-socialized boy who loves to romp in the garden with his canine friends. He is calm, sweet, and attentive, but energetic when not fully occupied. He is cautious and reserved around strangers. He walks very well on a leash and can ride in the car (although this isn't exactly his favorite activity). We are looking for a family for Rulis who already has experience with livestock guardian dogs. Children should already be adults. Rulis would also be very happy to have a companion of his own kind to help guard the house and a large, well-fenced garden. Rulis weighs 43 kg and is approximately 69 cm tall. He is neutered, dewormed, microchipped, vaccinated, and has an EU passport. If you would like to learn more about this great guy, please call 08762 7269977.

Willi is a cuddly, approximately 3-year-old Labrador-German Shepherd mix who, once you've won his heart, won't leave your side. He has a tough exterior, but an even softer core. Our dog trainers, with whom Willi regularly goes for training, agree. Unfortunately, Willi has moved several times in his life, which naturally brings its own challenges. Willi has basic obedience, but his leash walking and responsiveness outside still need improvement. He is moderately friendly with other dogs, but more so with female dogs. Willi is a happy-go-lucky bundle who's eager to finally settle down.

Attention, livestock guardian dog fans - here comes the loyal Naz.
Naz is a cheerful and totally lovable dog who loves to be petted and brushed. She can easily be left alone for hours and rides in the car. As is typical of the breed, Naz has a mind of her own and can be a bit stubborn at times.

Origin: Animal Welfare Romania (Smeura)
She is initially very reserved, but otherwise an interested, active dog. She still needs work on her leash training and basic commands.

Michi came to us because his previous owner was overwhelmed. There were reportedly biting incidents, which is why Michi will only be rehomed to people with experience with difficult dogs. Depending on his sympathy, he gets along well with other dogs. He can probably even be left alone for a few hours. Michi defends resources, but we will help his new owners manage this behavior in the future. Especially during the adjustment period, his new owners will have to strictly adhere to many rules.
If you would like to give Michi a home, you should plan on several visits to the animal shelter. This handsome guy needs patience and time to gain trust in people. He gets along well with other dogs, but he needs to get to know them first.
If you are interested in Michi, please use the contact form below or send an email to lassie@tierschutz-berlin.de, briefly describing your dog experience and Michi's potential home, or fill out the inquiry form below. We look forward to hearing from you!

Skyla came to her family from Romania about 3 years ago.
Unfortunately, over the past 3 years, it has been confirmed time and again that the human-dog combination simply isn't right here, and Skyla therefore urgently needs a new home, albeit with a heavy heart.
She is a young dog who still has a lot to learn, but who learns quickly.
Skyla is a sensitive dog who needs rules without pressure, because pressure triggers counter-pressure.

Hugo is unfortunately a typical victim of classified ad sales. He was given to people without much information, and they were overwhelmed by his behavior. Big, a bit chubby, and unruly? All of this probably applies to Hugo. He is an under-exercised young male who constantly questions boundaries and can be very stubborn. He finds maintaining personal space unnecessary and definitely needs some tutoring in etiquette. Hugo likes to hunt and isn't particularly picky about his prey, be it bicycles or joggers. He also finds overly energetic dogs or small dogs suitable for hunting. Being alone is absolutely not his cup of tea. He then howls loudly, thus expressing his displeasure. In our opinion, the ideal home would be someone with experience with dogs, who wouldn't have to leave him alone, and who would enjoy mentally and physically exercising him. There should be no children or other dogs in his new home. We recommend attending a dog training school. We are sure that Hugo can be a lot of fun if you are willing to invest time and effort.

Grobi was found tied to a tree and brought to us. Unfortunately, there was a bite incident, which is why this beautiful male can only be rehomed to experienced owners. Accordingly, Grobi is not suitable as a family dog. However, he has developed very well during his time with us. His frustration tolerance has improved significantly, and he no longer shows any tendency to bite.
Since Grobi is sensitive to noises, his new home would ideally be in a quiet, preferably rural area. To help him build trust, you should plan several visits to the shelter to get to know him better.
After an introduction period, Grobi gets along well with selected dogs, so he can be rehomed with a suitable female or neutered male.
If you would like to give Grobi a home, please send an email with your phone number to tiervermittlung@tierschutz-berlin.de. We look forward to hearing from you.

Hatschi was confiscated for violating animal protection laws. Unfortunately, things were far from perfect in his past, but he's developed superbly with us. He's a very typical representative of his breed, and Akita lovers will truly enjoy him.
He's quite reserved, even neutral, towards strangers and takes a while to get to know new people. Once he's gotten to know them and gained their trust, he's an absolutely loyal companion—he's certainly taken all of his keepers and dog walkers to his heart. He knows the muzzle, which he's developed a positive association with us, and wears it very confidently. He knows basic commands and enjoys working with his owners for praise and food. Outside, he's very neutral towards strangers and dogs and is easy to lead—he's often particularly charming with female dogs. However, on walks, you notice that Hatschi hasn't been socialized well enough and often reacts quite fearfully. For example, he is startled by mallards taking flight at a pond, and many environmental stimuli that should be natural for well-socialized dogs are "not entirely comfortable" with him. However, he never reacts aggressively in such situations; instead, he tends to retreat. We are therefore confident that with the right people at his side, he will find the world less scary with each passing month.
Due to his past, he is not suited to life in the city or a household with children or a lot of hustle and bustle. Quiet, dog-experienced people at his side who can give him trust and security would be just right for Hatschi. A confident female dog in the household would also offer him a lot of guidance. In his last known home, he unfortunately bit his owner's friend when he was harassed. Therefore, you should be aware that, as a stranger, you should not simply touch Hatschi. Akita friends will know this and be able to appreciate it well.
We expect that once Hatschi has settled in, he'll become a very relaxed, calm roommate and can easily be left alone for a few hours. We hope this sweet, curious boy finally gets his well-deserved "happy ending" – ideally in the suburbs or a rural location.

Youngster Aria happily accompanies her caregivers and curiously explores her surroundings on walks.
Aria is a livestock guardian dog mix, and with these dogs, the behavior of an adult dog develops gradually and much more slowly than with smaller dogs. This means that Aria will remain a "child" for quite some time.
Her future owners should be prepared for a certain amount of watchfulness—this is completely normal for livestock guardian dogs.

Our Moritz came to us as a surrendered dog and is now looking for a loving home with a securely fenced property with experienced dog owners who are familiar with caring for this breed. 🐕
This big guy is also not averse to long walks. He loves children, and according to his previous owner, he also gets along well with cats. 🐾❤️ With other dogs, it's all about sympathy.
Has Moritz piqued your interest? Then please contact us at the animal shelter. 🐾
shelter_name: Tierschutzverein Menschen für Tiere e.V. Spaichingen

description:
SOS Forgotten Paws e.V.
Charming young dog seeks his forever home! My name is Meda. I am a handsome male dog, born in February 2025, about 49 cm tall, and looking for my forever family. I feel incredibly comfortable in my foster home, but unfortunately, I can't stay here permanently. I love being around people, cuddling, and learning new things. I am a playful and very cheerful boy who is always enthusiastic about discovering new things. I am a little timid around men at first, but this can be overcome with patience, love, time, and sometimes a few treats. I get along wonderfully with other dogs and would therefore be ideal as a second dog. I simply feel safer and more comfortable with them by my side. Children are welcome in my new home, but they should be older and experienced with dogs, as I'm still young and sometimes a bit boisterous. I generally find cats interesting, but sometimes my hunting instinct comes out, which can certainly be managed with some training, as I'm very affectionate and not aggressive. I'm looking for people who have the time, patience, and joy to grow with me. Attending dog training classes would be perfect so I can learn even more and develop into a truly wonderful companion. If you're looking for an affectionate, active, and intelligent friend who will give you their heart, then I'm the perfect companion for you. I am being rehomed through the animal welfare organization SOS Vergessene Pfoten Tierschutz e.V. (SOS Forgotten Paws Animal Welfare) with a protection contract and for a protection fee of €550. I am, of course, vaccinated, microchipped, and dewormed. I am also already registered with Tasso. You can purchase a suitable, like-new safety harness, collar, and leash for me from our club. This starter kit will ensure that I feel safe, secure, and well cared for from the very beginning. You are welcome to visit me in Wetter as often as you like. Please be honest with yourselves and only contact us if you are genuinely interested. And above all, I need a forever home! Our behavior trainer, Lili, can work with us. Of course, we have not only great photos of me, but also videos. Tel.: 0160/96925678 Your Meda

We adopted Dobby, a Husky-German Shepherd mix, from one of our member associations. He originally came to the shelter following a seizure.
Dobby tends to defend resources. This primarily concerns food and sleeping places. However, with a little management and reading his body language, this is easily manageable. He is used to wearing a muzzle, but this will need to be further trained in his new home.
For Dobby, we are looking for experienced owners who can read his body language and accept his signals. With consistency and empathy, he will become a loyal family member. Dobby desires a life on a large, fenced farm where he can look after the animals, but still be close to the family. Moving into an apartment is unfortunately not an option for him. If problems arise, we are always available to provide professional support to Dobby's new family.

description:
Our Sulu came to the animal shelter because his owners could no longer care for him due to health reasons. He's a dog that loves his owner, alert and dominant, but also insecure and easily jumpy.
Sulu knows basic commands and can be left alone for up to five hours. Driving in a car still stresses him out—but if he has someone he trusts with him, he'll go along with it. His great love: a piece of banana. 🙂
When Sulu is insecure, he can unfortunately snap. What he lacks is security and consistency, loving consistency, and experience with dogs. He defends his food and toys and barks at passersby. He also tends to bark at other dogs.
We would like Sulu to find a home with experience with dogs that can provide him with the necessary structure, security, and stability. He's still young, so attending dog training would certainly do him good and teach him a lot.

Our Oskar is looking for a wonderful home. He was born on January 17, 2020, is neutered, and a bundle of energy. Oskar definitely has a mind of his own; he's still quite boisterous and extremely reluctant to share his food. We're looking for a home with experience with dogs for him.
Bruno is a real whirlwind, wild and boisterous. He's eager to please and therefore makes every effort to learn as much as possible as quickly as possible.

Spencer is an incredibly sweet, loving, and affectionate guy towards his caregivers. Typically for his breed, he bonds closely with familiar people.
He is rather suspicious of strangers and needs a lot of time to get to know them. In situations that unsettle him or are not as ritualized as Spencer is used to, he becomes stressed. In such situations, he would use his teeth.
Once the ice is broken, however, he is a loyal companion who enjoys long walks and walks excellently on a leash. Spencer also knows all common basic commands.
He is an agile guy who also wants to be mentally challenged. However, Spencer is definitely a quiet representative of his breed and not necessarily suited as a sporting or working dog.

He came to us some time ago as a rescue. He's now been released, and we're allowed to find the right home. Dobby is classified as dangerous due to a biting incident. This means he can only be walked on a leash and muzzle! He originally came to us as a puppy from abroad. We are now at least the fifth owner, even though he's only 3 years old. Dobby is at his best with us and is one of our dogs with the fewest problems. He can communicate clearly and subtly, both with other dogs and with people. He runs easily with our dog group. Dobby learns quickly and accepts rules and boundaries very well. Off-leash, he is curious about strangers. He's also friendly with children. He is alert but easily lets us break him off. We are looking for people for Dobby who are aware of their responsibility. Who will nevertheless take this dog seriously and not trivialize the biting incident. People who don't perceive the muzzle as something "bad." The muzzle doesn't restrict him, but rather allows him much more freedom. And he wears it without any problems. People who can read a dog's body language and who are interested in working with him, encouraging him, and taking him through the temperament test—which won't be a problem with him either.

Unsere süße Gina kam als Sicherstellung zu uns.
Rassetypisch ist sie ihren Menschen sehr loyal gegenüber und tritt Fremden misstrauisch gegenüber.
Gina hat leider nicht viel an Erziehung kennengelernt.
Für sie suchen wir rasseerfahrene Menschen, die Lust und die Zeit haben, sie wohlwollend anzuleiten und mit gemeinsam zu lernen.

Tyler is a fearful, young male. He is socially compatible, which is why we would like to find a stable first dog for Tyler. Tyler is good on a leash, but he still has a lot to learn. He is very cautious around strangers. We see this reserved young dog in a rural setting with a house and land, and would also be happy with families with children over 13.
About me

We originally adopted the young mixed-breed male Marvel along with other young dogs from another animal welfare organization. After a long period of rehoming, he returned to Sonnenhof because his family was no longer able to cope with him, and he is now looking for a new home.
He gets along well with other dogs, depending on how well he gets along.
The placement of one of our dogs usually proceeds as follows:
