description:
Cookie was confiscated for violating animal protection laws. Our animal keepers describe her as a princess with a few issues. Once she trusts someone, she's open-minded, a joyful little whirlwind, and cute. But she would bite in some everyday situations if left unsecured.
Cookie is easy to train, although food as a resource is a major source of conflict for her, and she already knows common basic commands. Hunting games are taboo for her. She is personable and currently only friendly to people she knows.
She cannot climb stairs and will receive free lifelong treatment at our veterinary practice for her severe knee arthritis and early arthritis in her elbows.
We are looking for a home for Cookie with knowledgeable breed experts. She will only be rehomed to people who already have experience dealing with dangerous dogs. In her new ground-floor home, she needs a fenced-off area. She is not suitable for children. Getting to know her at the shelter will require a longer period of regular visits. Please note that due to her breed, she must be muzzled and kept on a leash, and landlord permission is required for her care.

The beautiful Kamal comes from Ukraine and came to us via a seizure. He initially lived here with his girlfriend (the blonde dog in the pictures) – the two recovered from the traumatic events of their past under the loving care of their carers. The dog has since moved out, and Kamal is still looking for his new owners.
Kamal has an incredibly sad story: He and his girlfriend Sonya were probably originally street dogs. At some point, they were captured and taken to Kyiv's municipal animal shelter, Borodyanka. When the city came under fire in the spring of 2022, the director of the shelter and her staff fled the premises, leaving the animals locked up and uncared for. For five weeks, no one cared for the 485 dogs, among others. Only about 260 of them survived the gruesome ordeal; Kamal and Sonya were among the lucky ones. After their rescue, they lived for a few weeks at the home of a Ukrainian animal rights activist in Kyiv, who arranged a final home for them in the Netherlands—at least, that was the plan. On the way to the Netherlands, however, they were stranded in Berlin because one of the volunteer drivers for the onward transport had dropped out at short notice. Ultimately, the dogs were confiscated by the veterinary office and taken to an animal shelter. They were both still far too thin and extremely timid—no wonder. They have escaped the dog hell on earth.
After some time with us, with lots of good food, medical care, and attention, Kamal is finally ready to move into his forever home. This handsome male is a sweet, personable dog when trusted, but he is very difficult outside. Kamal is currently undergoing muzzle training with us because, on walks, he resolutely moves forward when passing strangers and dogs. Intensive individual work using humane methods with a good dog trainer is therefore strongly recommended. Kamal hasn't experienced much in his life so far, but he's trying very hard to understand what people want from him. Being left alone with other dogs is no problem, but whether he can stay completely alone would have to be tested and trained accordingly. Kamal sometimes reacts uncertainly and fearfully in new situations, and he panics at the vet. 🙁 A lot of sensitive, patient training will be necessary here to take some of the fear out of the necessary vet visits. If Kamal feels threatened, he might snap out of fear—he doesn't mean any harm. He defends his food. Who could blame him, after what he's been through?
Kamal is very happy to move in with a nice, confident female dog as a second dog. He likes his female companions very much, but with males, it's all about sympathy.

Pepito came from a seizure of several Cane Corsos in August 2023.
Until his seizure, Pepito only knew life in a stable with an adjacent run in his previous group (pack housing). He didn't know a leash or the usual basic commands, such as eating from a food bowl, car rides, the inside of a house, etc.


When out for walks without major distractions, Pepito is mostly easy to walk on a leash. If he feels stressed, he may circle you – we still recommend using a safety harness (or a GPS tracker if necessary).

Rexi originally came from a breeder and is currently in an animal shelter in Hungary.
The little dog, 34 cm and 6 kg, is still a bit shy and overwhelmed by all the new experiences.
He already walks on a leash quite well, and he shows no fear of people.
If you would like to adopt Rexi, please contact

Taffy came to us as a surrender because she was becoming increasingly insecure in her old home and had even snapped. She's very reserved at first, but once she gains trust, she proves to be a real joker. She likes people who make her feel safe and can read their body language. She reacts more skeptically to men and children than to women. Since Taffy bonds quickly, she would be perfect with a single person and as an only dog.

Grandma Amica is a very sweet soul.
She is open and friendly towards everyone and enjoys being petted.
Amica loves going for walks and runs easily in a group of dogs. However, she doesn't listen very well anymore, so she has to stay on a leash. But she does this very well.
She is also a real dream dog in the home environment. She is house-trained and can be left alone for a few hours. The main thing is that she has a cozy basket in which she can take a comfortable nap.

The pretty dog Shiwa is friendly, sociable, and loves to play with other dogs. In her new home, she would love to have a confident first dog to look up to.
Shiva is initially reserved and unsure of people. She needs some time to gain trust – but then she's already showing how much she enjoys closeness and affection. She particularly thrives when treats are involved, as food is a wonderful way to motivate and encourage her.
Since Shiwa has never had a real home before, she has a lot to learn. In the animal shelter, she's already house-trained and walks quite well on a leash. With patience and loving consistency, she'll surely make further progress quickly.
We're looking for a quiet, rural home for Shiwa with sensitive people who will give her time and help her settle in step by step. Children in the household should be older and understand a sensitive dog.

Paco, a Husky mix, came to us at Sonnenhof from one of our member clubs, along with Tobi. They originally came to an animal shelter because their previous owners had sadly passed away.
Paco pulls a lot on the leash, and his strong need for exercise also makes it clear that he wants to be physically and mentally challenged. He is very eager to learn and enjoys training that keeps him busy while also providing him with clear structures.

description:
Miko originally came from an animal protection organization abroad and was surrendered because he had bitten several times in the past. In the shelter, he gets along well with other male and female dogs, but due to his behavior towards people, he is better kept as an only dog. If he feels threatened, he reacts with noticeable aggression. However, he wears his muzzle reliably and will likely need it in various everyday situations.
Miko is a very sensitive dog who needs calm people who he can look up to. He already knows some basic commands and is house-trained. He is used to riding in the car, jumps into the car crate, and is calm during the journey. He has also shown himself to be very good on a leash in the shelter. He also loves water.
Our Miko is not a cuddly dog, but he wants to be close to his caregivers. He enjoys spending his breaks with his animal keepers at the shelter. He has difficulty dealing with stress and frustration and needs careful management, for example, when it comes to feeding. He defends resources and his territory.
Miko is not a dog for a hectic life in the city or an apartment building, where he encounters people he cannot avoid every day in confined spaces in the hallway and/or elevator. Simply "tolerating" situations is very difficult for him. He is therefore looking for a home in a more rural, quiet environment with a house or apartment with a separate entrance.

Blue came to our shelter as a surrendered dog. Everyday life in the shelter isn't easy for him. He's insecure and seems somewhat overwhelmed by the situation. Blue's trust has to be earned, which he finds noticeably easier with women than with men. Once his trust has been gained, he is very exuberant, playful, and happy, but also very protective. Blue knows basic commands such as sit and stay, but he still needs a certain amount of basic training regarding his behavior. He currently defends what he considers a boundary violation with growling and defensive, threatening body language, so he is currently only walked with a muzzle, which is not a problem for him. He is a very intelligent and eager-to-learn dog with a considerable hunting instinct, who, with appropriate training, will grow into a very confident dog. For Blue, we're looking for a home with a lot of dog experience, without children, where we can continue to work with him, possibly with professional support. His compatibility with other dogs is based on sympathy, although female dogs are more likely to score points here.

Please note: Donnie is only suitable for a shelter-like environment. His new home must offer the opportunity to handle him with safety training (we trained him to wear a muzzle and leash without contact). A fence system is therefore required where Donnie can be kept in contact with people, yet shielded from direct confrontation. A kennel (with a heated indoor enclosure) and, ideally, a dog room with outdoor access are ideal for this.
Donnie was found abandoned. This handsome mixed breed is a very lively, strong, and people-oriented guy who tries very hard to please his two-legged friends. He is used to and loves riding in cars. He can easily run along with familiar dogs.
For Donnie, we are looking for active people with dog experience who can spend a lot of time with him and who feel confident about a four-legged friend with plenty of energy and a hunting instinct. A rural environment would be ideal. Other dogs, cats, and children should not live in the household. Please note that due to his breed, Donnie must be muzzled and kept on a leash, and landlord permission is required for his ownership.
Who would like to give Donnie a chance? Please contact his animal caretakers at +49 30 76 888-173.

Graf came to us after being confiscated for violating animal protection laws. He now walks quite well on a leash and is easy to train with food. He is accustomed to wearing a muzzle and will need it in the future, even in challenging situations. Graf has difficulty dealing with stress and is prone to displacement behavior or aggression, and can therefore only be rehomed with dog professionals.
Although he is used to walking with a dog group, he will only be rehomed as a single dog. Unfortunately, he dislikes strange dogs at all, but can be led past them with the necessary distance. He also knows basic commands.
We are looking for people with experience with dogs and breeds for Graf. Children and other animals should not live in the household. He is also not suitable for the inner city; a quiet, rural area would be ideal. Due to his breed, landlord permission is required in many places, and he must be muzzled and kept on a leash in public. He should not be played with hunting games. Please note that several visits to the shelter are necessary to rehome Graf.
If you would like to give Graf a home, please send a meaningful email to tiervermittlung@tierschutz-berlin.de, including your telephone number and a description of your living conditions and any experience with the breed, or carefully fill out the form below. We look forward to hearing from you!

The lovable Anusch is initially rather reserved around strangers. Even with people she knows, this sweet dog needs some time to gain trust. But with a bribe, Anusch can be persuaded to give her a little petting.
We are looking for a quieter home for Anusch, as she needs to gradually get used to life with a human. Loud and numerous stimuli are still a bit overwhelming for her at the moment.
Anusch can already walk well on a leash and enjoys sniffing around.
Toto came to the shelter due to circumstances. He's a quiet fellow who wants to start over.

Charles, real name PRINCE Charles, came to us after being confiscated for violating animal protection laws. This handsome brindle male dog doesn't like strangers. He is very friendly with familiar people and enjoys being petted and receiving attention. He connects with women more quickly than with men. Despite this soft inner core, you have to earn his trust. He is aggressive towards both other dogs and strangers—whether passersby or joggers—and should not be underestimated: Charles knows how big and powerful he is. He also dislikes children, neither on the street nor in his home.
Therefore, he needs a human who won't be intimidated or unsettled by this. He must always wear a muzzle when walking, but walks well on a leash as long as he can keep a distance of 5 meters from other dogs. He gets along well with female dogs if they like him, but should preferably live alone in his new home. He chases cats and usually doesn't react at all to birds. The male has discovered his great love in the water: He loves to swim and jumps into his pool with great joy.
Generally speaking, Charles is a smart, eager-to-learn dog with whom there is certainly still a lot to learn. Therefore, we are only rehoming him with confident owners who are experienced with dogs and already know how to deal with difficult and large dogs. He needs a home in a more rural setting, ideally a house with a securely fenced garden. Children should not live in the household. Charles's adjustment period will be rather lengthy and difficult; he often reacts insecurely and stressed in unfamiliar surroundings and when the light changes, so he will need time to settle in. However, he can also be left alone for a few hours. Although Charles is often seen as a pure guard dog due to his size, we do not want to rehome him as such, but rather as a member of the family. This handsome male wants to be close to his people. Please plan several visits to the shelter to get to know him. Charles will only be adopted after a preliminary check. Furthermore, the veterinary office will be informed of his future stay based on his medical history.
We are certain: There is a perfect home for Charles, too. Do you have any questions or are you interested? Please contact his animal caretakers at Benji-Haus by phone at +49 30 76 888-212 or fill out the inquiry form below. We look forward to hearing from you.
Elli is our loving whirlwind. This pretty German Shepherd is a real cuddly toy, but we mustn't forget why she ended up with us at the shelter. She has a problem, and that is her explosive power.

description: Loki is one of nine puppies we took in from Croatia, along with their mother. The large family was found in a Croatian junkyard – their luck, because otherwise they would hardly have survived. Loki came to our farm in May and spent weeks trembling in his basket, afraid of everyone and everything. Since then, we've trained Loki a lot, all at his own pace, and he's become more outgoing and enjoys spending time with his people (he has a few favorites). He needs lots of cuddles and spends a lot of time with us around the farm so he can get to know everything. He now lets us put a harness on him and can even go for short walks with his familiar people. Loki is still a fearful dog. He's afraid of every noise and stranger and retreats, but then he comes out again because he is somewhat curious. He trusts his people so much that he no longer needs to hide completely. He's already been around an apartment and gotten used to getting into a car, which he still finds scary. Everything is being practiced slowly and at his own pace. Anyone who wants to meet Loki will need to come here often to build the necessary trust. We would like Loki to have a house or apartment with a garden, as he won't be able to go for walks at first. It should be in a quiet, rural location; calm children aged 12 and up would be fine. Experience with fearful dogs is a must. Unfortunately, we don't know how he reacts to cats. He enjoys the company of smaller dogs, especially females. If there's already a small, confident dog in the household, that would be ideal. Loki still needs to learn all the basics of dog training, very slowly. It will be tiring and challenging, and there may always be setbacks. He's not yet house-trained, as he's never lived in an apartment before. Who would like to give Loki a chance and get to know him? Please contact Martina Achilles at 0162-7100897 or by email at aktivverein@aktiv-fuer-hunde-in-not.de. Videos of Loki are already available on our website: https://www.aktiv-fuer-hunde-in-not.de/vermittlung-hunde/loki
shelter_name: Aktiv für Hunde in Not e.V.

description: Astor comes from our friend Bea in Slovakia. Unfortunately, he was injured in a fight at our animal shelter. His wounds required veterinary treatment. Since then, he has been afraid of strange dogs. Nevertheless, he lives with a female dog. Astor is reserved around strangers; you have to convince him that you have his best interests at heart. He enjoys long, extensive walks, just like his people. We are looking for people with experience with dogs for Astor, but without small children. A well-behaved female dog that Astor can look up to would certainly be an advantage.

Cox is a very sweet, approximately 6-year-old, cuddly Labrador mix. He loves going for walks, although commands and leash training still need to be improved. Cox is moderately sociable and requires a muzzle for vet visits. He is very sweet and cuddly with his caregivers. Due to his history, Cox unfortunately has a problem with a certain type of man, which would need to be tested if he is interested. With women, Cox is an absolute dream dog and will put up with anything. He is always willing to be trained, given the right bribe.

This handsome male is currently a shell of his former self. Without a firm footing in life, he doesn't yet know what to do. Bought as an eight-week-old puppy, Michel was meant to do exactly what a livestock guardian is meant to do – guard goats and the property that surrounds them. A dog that is allowed to do the exact job for which its breed was originally bred is something we certainly welcome – but only if it is approached correctly.  Unfortunately, this was not the case in Michel's case.  Apart from the two Ovcharka bitches that also lived on the property, as well as the owners and their families, Michel didn't get to know anything (apart from his job of guarding). So Michel lived and functioned within his system until the mood changed.
After a full-blown bite incident, his fear of the male dog became too great. Michel was locked away on the farm. As is typical for many dogs for whom we and other animal shelters across Germany request placement, in Michel's case, too, the authorities did not want to tackle the problem together with the dog. Experts called in spoke out against official euthanasia because the dog was not dangerous. So Michel remained in his shed until the authorities insisted that he be surrendered.
Without any environmental socialization, the imposing male dog was completely shocked by the existence of a world outside his garden. Since arriving at the animal shelter, Michel has repeatedly faced what he sees as insurmountable hurdles. Even the slightest touch of his collar, people in his kennel, pulling on the leash, or similar things that are normally everyday for dogs trigger panic in Michel, flight, and, in certain situations, defensive behavior. Michel was not allowed to experience anything, never learned how to learn, and on the other hand, never had to endure anything. As a result, he has no problem-solving skills or problem-management skills.
Even though Michel's claws have already left a few dents in our lives, we agree with the expert opinion that prevented Michel's death and are happy that we can now show him the world. We're already seeing initial successes, and the progress is in some cases greater and faster than expected. Nevertheless, it requires patience, perseverance, and a well-fitting muzzle from everyone involved.
Prisca wasn't supposed to be alive anymore. She was in a kill shelter in France, and the date for her last injection was practically already set.

Unfortunately, the graceful dog Sira had little contact with people in her first weeks of life. Therefore, during her first few weeks with us, she found it unusual to cooperate with people and reacted fearfully.
Despite her progress, Sira is still very fearful of strangers. So, she definitely needs a little time and patience to get to know them.
Other dogs are especially important to Sira. She gets along well with all other dogs and is very attached to her canine friends. She is also learning how to interact with people through confident dogs, and this is helping her enormously with her development. Therefore, we would like to place Sira in a multi-dog home.
In addition to her fearful side, Sira can also be alert. She immediately alerts strangers by barking—which is why she will likely bark a little in her future home as well. However, the barking will only last for a limited time.

Ronny came to the Berlin animal shelter after being confiscated for violating animal protection laws. Unfortunately, he has already been involved in a single bite incident.
This strong male is obedient and attentive, but he is initially skeptical of strangers. Interested parties should therefore plan several visits to the shelter to get to know him in peace.
For Ronny, we are looking for people with extensive experience with the breed who can offer him consistently confident and clear leadership. His basic obedience also needs work. Ronny dislikes other male dogs at all. Please note that Ronny is subject to muzzle and leash requirements, and in Berlin, landlord permission is required for his ownership. He is not suitable for children at all.
If you are interested in Ronny, please contact his animal caretakers at the Reha-Haus by phone at +49 30 76 888-204 or -173. We look forward to your inquiry!

Our Klaus is a model student and has blossomed from a distrustful dog into a docile, loyal fellow. After a period of adjustment, he has shown himself to be a willing learner who is friendly and obedient to people he trusts. His exuberant nature and working with him are great fun.
In his previous life, he only ever trusted a very few select people, whom he had known since his puppyhood. His insecurity probably led him to try to bite. He rarely allowed strangers to visit him. His previous home was probably too unsafe for him, which rubbed off on him. With secure and confident guidance, Klaus can also relax and accepts this gratefully. Nevertheless, you should be aware that Klaus may be prone to jealousy again in his new home.
At just under 40 kilos, further work should be done on his leash training. He's used to being left alone for hours at a time, as well as traveling in cars, buses, and trains. He's generally friendly toward other dogs, but can, of course, be provoked by large, fussy males. Since Klaus is an intelligent little fellow, he can also open doors and jump over fences. His property must therefore be securely fenced and fenced high enough.
For our Klaus, we're looking for loving, patient people who have experience with difficult dogs and enjoy training and plenty of exercise. A quiet household without many visitors and children in a quiet or even rural area would be ideal.

Lively, curious, and cheeky—that's probably the best way to describe our Diego. This little male has a real energy and needs someone who can stand up to him and his stubbornness.
He probably has some dachshund in him; that would definitely suit him well in terms of personality. He gets along quite well with other dogs, but cats and small animals shouldn't live in his forever home.
Unfortunately, Diego was returned from adoption because a household with children was too much for him. A quiet household with dog experience and a passion for working with dogs would be perfect for him.

description:
Pofi currently lives in a Hungarian animal shelter. He originally came from a kill shelter.
Pofi is 45cm tall, weighs 16 kg, and is neutered.
He is friendly with other dogs, likes people, and is not shy. However, he doesn't like cats.
He's already quite good at walking on a leash, but he certainly still has a lot to learn.

Stone was seized for animal welfare reasons. He currently appears to be a rather stubborn, lively, and unruly male. This needs to be redirected so that he can cope well in everyday life. Attending dog training would be beneficial for him. He already knows basic commands.
Stone is very insecure in new situations and starts licking his paws. Because of this, his front paws are already a bit sore. The current situation is anything but ideal for him, and we are looking for a home with experience with dogs, ideally with the breed, where he can relax. Ideally, his new home will also have experience with more difficult dogs. With a permanent caregiver at his side, he will feel more secure, and there's a good chance that he will also become calmer. He doesn't like strangers at first, so several visits will be necessary to get to know him.
Due to his breed, Stone must be muzzled and kept on a leash, and a landlord's permit is required. If he likes them, he could probably be kept as a second dog—this would have to be tested. His new home should be fairly quiet, and there should be no children living in the household.
If you are interested in our Stone, please contact his animal caretakers at +49 30 76888-264 or fill out the inquiry form below. We look forward to hearing from you.

Tayo is a people-oriented, active, and docile dog who needs a stable structure in the household. He enjoys being close to people, but is not a cuddly dog. Tayo has a strong food and resource guarding instinct that must be dealt with. He loves cooling off in streams or swimming in the Rems River or a lake. Despite his age, he can sometimes be a real silly dog. Tayo regularly participates in the SocialWalk group and behaves towards other dogs according to his sympathy. He enjoys daily walks with his caregivers and is very attentive.
We are looking for a home for Tayo without other animals with very experienced people (couples or singles) in a quiet environment. It is important that they can read his body language very well and respect it.

Collin quickly wins hearts with his beautiful eyes. He is a rather gentle male, yet also has a cheeky and energetic nature.
Collin hasn't experienced much of everyday human life in his life so far, as he grew up with his siblings in a Romanian shelter.
Collin already enjoys going for walks, always seeks out the company of familiar people, and discovers how wonderful it is to be petted.
Nevertheless, he still reacts very insecurely in some situations. Therefore, Collin is looking for people who will give him enough security and a sense of self-assurance. Because pity is out of place when dealing with him – that makes him even more insecure.

Our Rocky has a big mouth, but there's not much behind it...
When you see him in the kennel, you initially think he's not going to be a good fit. But once you get to know him, you quickly realize that life in the shelter is simply too much, too loud, and too stressful for him.
Even when we go for a walk, he shows a much better side: curious, friendly, and energetic.
Rocky simply hasn't learned much in his life so far, and catching up on this at the age of three is quite possible, but it does require a bit of dog experience.

May we introduce: Our adoption dog, Chico. This beautiful four-year-old Labrador Pit Bull mix is a truly loyal and wonderful dog once you've gained his trust. He is initially suspicious of strangers. Due to his breed, his care requires a certificate of competence. Chico is neutered and was given to us due to a move. Chico is only being adopted as a single dog. If you are interested, please stop by and our foster carers will be happy to provide further information.

Ares, a Continental Bulldog with special effects, has been in the shelter for a little over a year now. Ares visited the Hellhound Foundation for a professional assessment of his special effects. The good news: he didn't have to stay there and isn't a hellhound. "Just because someone stumbles and loses their bearings doesn't mean they're lost forever!" ~ Charles Xavier. That's the quote Vanessa Bokrr gave our Ares. Read Vanessa Bokrr's assessment from the Hellhound Foundation here: Assessment of Ares: The two-and-a-half-year-old male Bulldog mix has been in the shelter kennel for a year now and is looking for people who are familiar with the issue of a "second-hand, docked, bulldog" and its challenges. Ares's ears were lost in Turkey, and once he arrived in Germany, he was resold after a short time. A thoughtless purchase, as it turned out, the buyer surrendered the dog to the shelter as a stray after just a few days. The sad thing about such unfortunate chain of events is that information about the dog gets lost, and you end up with a veritable mosaic of behaviors whose rationale isn't always immediately apparent. For example, Ares chooses his own caregivers and terrorizes the rest by jumping on the bars, threatening, and attacking. For this reason, Ares has already been fitted with a muzzle by the shelter, and he wears it without any problems. When Ares was with us, he displayed insecure behavior and immediately reacted to harassment with an attack. Unfortunately, this is a common behavior in dogs who, due to too many changes of owners, have developed attachment disorders and social neglect because they never really had a chance to put down roots. This means that dogs like Ares begin to develop their own strategies with which they think they can solve their problems and worries. Of course, "attack is never the best defense," and so people who adopt Ares shouldn't assume that he means it in a bad way, but rather that he simply can't do anything else in some situations because no one has ever taught him how. A dog like Ares should therefore be given to very responsible owners who don't see the muzzle as a punishment, but rather as an opportunity to accompany their dog in his development process responsibly and safely for everyone. Because when Ares attacks, he doesn't need to resist, nor does he need a person nearby who gets scared and becomes hysterical. He needs to learn that his behavior is undesirable and be prevented from escalating further. In our case, we were able to achieve this by intercepting Ares in the act of attack and placing him by his collar in front of us. Since he didn't expect such a reaction, he looked at us briefly, which we used as an opportunity to send him away and to convey to him that he wasn't allowed to be there when he behaved like that. So you pull him back from his attack and threaten him away. As soon as he lets go of his perceived opponent and evades the body language threat, it's just as important to invite him back into the situation with a gentle body language gesture and let him participate again. You don't want to punish him, but simply show him which behavior is desired and which undesirable. Dogs communicate analogically – that is, they indicate their state of mind and intentions through body language, facial expressions, and gestures. It's always said that where the nose points, the dog is thinking. If he looks at the sausage, he'll eat it; if he looks into the woods, you'll go for a walk alone shortly afterward because Waldi is hunting. This also applies to Ares, but his flat muzzle and curled tail mean that many people don't understand him well, which is another reason why his speech and actions often seem a bit exaggerated. If you're not understood, you just raise your voice. Ares, because he's been passed around so much in his short life, is a lone fighter who looks out for his own skin first and foremost. Typical of a bulldog, he remains very stubborn and defends himself according to the motto "attack is the best defense." People who want to give Ares a home need knowledge of expressive behavior and communication. Furthermore, a high degree of responsibility is required to avoid Ares being classified as a dangerous dog. Unfortunately, it happens all too often that dogs are given too much perceived freedom out of pity and then fall back into old habits. Otherwise, he's easy to handle in all other everyday situations and can handle a lot. He rides well in the car, he's cuddly, he eats well, and he loves to sleep. He loves walks as much as treats. Strangers, pushy, and aggressive dogs quickly have an "Aha!" moment... smarter through ouch, in other words. For Ares, we wish for a home that looks with an unclouded view at the nature and character of such an involuntary vagabond and recognizes and takes seriously his potential.

Anton came to us at the animal shelter as a stray. This lively male is a very alert, affectionate dog who would uncompromisingly defend his owner against strangers and makes this very clear when on a leash. He is house-trained, knows basic commands, is familiar with car rides, and gives up his toys on command. He is very easy to motivate with toys and food and has already made great progress. We suspect that he can be left alone for up to three hours.
We would like to rehome Anton with a single owner, as he unconditionally defends his owner. His new owner should already have experience with his breed and difficult dogs, and should be confident and responsible. A house with a securely fenced yard is also required. Children should not live in the household. At the animal shelter, he gets along well with female dogs.

Please note: Nero is only suitable for keeping in a shelter-like environment. His new home must offer the opportunity to handle him with safety training (contact-free muzzle and leash training, as we have trained him to do). A fence system is therefore necessary where Nero can be kept in contact with people, but still shielded from direct confrontation. A kennel (with a heated indoor enclosure) and, ideally, a dog room with outdoor access are ideal for this.
Nero came to us via a seizure. A lot has gone wrong with this handsome guy so far. He has had five previous owners, and there have been several serious biting incidents. Now he's landed with us, and we sincerely hope that even a dog like him will be able to have a fresh start outside of our shelter.
Nero is quite annoyed by people, their strange, unpredictable behavior, and generally all the back and forth of his past, and his frustration tolerance towards people is correspondingly very low. He lacks the trust that the other end of the leash can also offer understanding, clear structure, and security. He ALWAYS needs a muzzle when interacting with people, even with his closest caregivers. When out for walks, he tends to change his orientation in certain situations. Once he's settled in, he can easily be left alone for about six hours and is also used to riding on public transport. Generally, Nero enjoys walks and contact with his caregivers. He's also easy to walk on a leash and can behave well on walks.
We know that Nero will never be suitable for an ordinary household. Unfortunately, far too much has gone wrong in his past, leading to irreversible mistrust. Nevertheless, we hope that Nero will have his own home outside of our shelter, with more individual attention and daily walks with dog experts who have appropriate facilities for keeping dangerous dogs.

Buddy has been living with us at the animal shelter for almost five years now, far too long in our opinion. Like so many black dogs, he is often overlooked.
Buddy has grown older now. Despite his age, Buddy loves long walks and enjoys activities that also challenge him mentally.
Buddy knows all the basic commands, but he is very aware of who he should follow them with and who he shouldn't. He is a very intelligent dog, and therefore consistent and clear handling is important for him. 
Buddy needs 2-3 walks to get to know a new person. Once he has met that person, he is the most loyal companion you could wish for. Buddy is a big water baby and loves to swim. He also loves to fetch balls in the water.

Nele, our mixed-breed lady, is a dog that you have to get to know before you can love her.
Unfortunately, she hasn't had the chance to experience much in the past and hasn't always had good experiences.
She is making great progress with us every day and has wrapped everyone who knows her around her finger.
Nele doesn't get along with most dogs. But it always depends on the other person.

This heartwarming look belongs to our Baddy. However, he is considerably more demanding than his loyal gaze suggests. Therefore, he is looking for a home with people who have experience with more difficult dogs.
Baddy is a lively, self-confident fellow. He is house-trained and knows basic commands. Whether he can be left alone and ride well in the car will need to be tested and, if necessary, patiently practiced.
At first, Baddy was difficult to handle with us. He hates strangers and unfamiliar things and gets stressed easily. Out of insecurity, he tends to go forward with strangers—there is a risk that he might bite. He is friendly with people he knows.
We are looking for an experienced home for Baddy in a quiet, low-stress environment. Children should not live in the household. Several visits to gain Baddy's trust will be necessary. Please also note that due to his breed, a landlord's permit is required for his care, and he is subject to muzzle and leash requirements.

SOS Forgotten Paws e.V.
SOS Forgotten Paws Animal Welfare e.V.
My name is Gino, and according to the vet, I was born in June 2021. At 53 cm, I'm quite small for a livestock guardian dog. But I have a heart of gold! Since I'm a herding dog, you should already have a lot of experience with dogs and be very familiar with my breed. To make life easier for us both, my specific needs in everyday life should be taken into account. Because I'm still very agile and full of motivation, my training needs to be consistent but loving. According to the breed description, I should be vigilant and protective, which I am to some extent when it comes to other dogs. I get along better with smaller dogs than with larger ones. But even here, it always depends on whether we get along. For this, I need consistent leadership and clear rules. With the right people by my side and enough to keep me busy, I will be a loyal companion. Otherwise, I am incredibly loyal and loving. I look forward to discovering the world with you and having a loving, safe home where I can feel secure. I am naturally cuddly and love spending time with my humans and older, steady, dog-experienced children. My friendly nature will make it easy for you to feel completely at ease around me. Unfortunately, I haven't met any cats yet, and a house with a secure fence is essential. My dog walker, Jenni, always says I'm a fantastic guy. And yes, what can I say? Soon you'll see us both on TV on Vox. We're looking forward to meeting you, Gino and Jenni!!!
I am being rehomed through the animal welfare organization SOS Vergessene Pfoten Tierschutz e.V. with a protection contract and for a protection fee of €550. I am, of course, vaccinated, microchipped, dewormed, neutered, and already registered with Tasso. You can purchase a brand-new safety harness, collar, and leash that fit me perfectly from our rescue organization. This starter kit will ensure that I feel safe, secure, and well cared for right from the beginning. So, have I piqued your interest? Then you should give us a call and arrange a visit to see me in Hagen. This way, you can meet me in person and learn even more about me and my sweet and gentle nature. We would be delighted if you followed us in our Facebook group, on Instagram, and on TikTok. There you'll get lots of insights into our work, the association, and of course, our furry friends. Animal Encounters on Saturday, November 1st, 2025, from 2:00 PM to 5:00 PM and on Sunday, November 2nd, 2025, from 3:00 PM to 5:00 PM at Alter Henkhauser Weg 58 in 58119 Hagen. We look forward to your visit! Tel.: 0160/96925678 I'm looking forward to seeing you! Your beautiful Gino

Even at a young age, Ace was a real bully and always rolled up his sleeves, ready for a fight. Now he acts much more carefully and observes situations very closely before firing up the throttle. As is so often the case in social interactions, with Ace, too, "the tone makes the music" – respectful interaction is very important to him and the key to a functioning relationship. The harsher the tone, the quicker Ace's comments fall on deaf ears, and he likes to remind the other person who they are and who they are actually talking to.
Everyday life with Ace is often like a shared dance. He now has a fixed choreography. Daily life at the animal shelter is precisely timed and gives Ace a structure to orient himself by. You float through the day together, everyone knows each other's next steps, you tune into one another and don't step on each other's toes in everyday life – but it's also about inspiring one another and helping each other move forward. To ensure that we don't get stuck in the same place amidst all the routine, we're constantly striving to develop and hone our daily performance. Everyone's freedom is also a big issue here. When physically harassed (giving spot-on medication, removing ticks), he often resorts to his tried-and-true way of getting space. You can either make the situation more comfortable for him so he doesn't trigger in the first place, or use it as a training measure to discuss the relationship and their respective statuses. Wearing a muzzle is incredibly important, especially in such moments, and it will remain a constant companion for Ace in the future.
Even when interacting with other dogs, the black shaggy dog tries to present himself, testing his counterpart's boundaries in a more or less subtle way. His fuse has now lengthened a little, and he's learned to let things slide sometimes. If the match is right, being with a fellow dog is a welcome change, especially during his time in the animal shelter. Nevertheless, dog encounters are a classic problem for Ace, too. On the leash, he generally behaves very externally oriented. It is therefore important to make it clear to him that he is not responsible for resolving every situation, but that the human at the other end of the leash takes over this task. Exuding calm and composure in stressful moments is a real challenge, but this basic disposition also helps Ace keep a cool head. Whether in dog encounters specifically or during walks in general, Ace still has a lot to learn. Since he sometimes attacks his owners when jumping up, when frustrated, or to test them, he is muzzled during these activities. By harnessing his eagerness to work, you can redirect him and calmly exit the situation.
With the right people, this black chaotic dog can become a truly good companion. Experience with dogs, stamina, and strong nerves are extremely important for this. Because the risk of a biting incident is too high, Ace should be kept muzzled consistently in his new home. This way, you can challenge, encourage, and grow together without running any major risks.

Eddy came to us after being confiscated. He is now in the training center because he would lunge at his animal keepers in stressful situations with his whole body. At 38.9 kg, not everyone can withstand that. However, he is now easy to handle and no longer lunges at other people, even in stressful situations. He shows strangers (both men and women) that he does not want to be bothered by growling and staring. He knows the common basic commands and is easily motivated with food. He is an alert dog who takes good care of his property.
The powerful Eddy will only be rehomed to people with the appropriate expertise and who have the necessary physical requirements to keep such a dog. He is not a city dog and needs a rural environment. There should be no children or other dogs in his new home.
If you would like to meet Eddy, please contact his animal care team at +49 30 76888-220 or fill out the form below. Please plan several visits to the shelter so you can get to know him in peace. We look forward to hearing from you.

Eiman musste leider sein Zuhause aufgrund von gesundheitlichen Gründen seiner Vorbesitzer verlassen. Nun sitzt der arme Senior bei uns im Tierheim.
Der arabische Name Eiman bedeutet unter anderem Treue. Und genau das trifft auf das Kerlchen auch zu. Denn gegenüber seinen Bezugspersonen ist Eiman eine wirklich treue Seele und genießt Streicheleinheiten und Aufmerksamkeit. Auch geht er gerne spazieren und erkundet dabei neugierig seine Umgebung. Eiman kennt das Leben an der Seite von Menschen bereits gut. Zudem kann er auch problemlos ein paar Stunden alleine bleiben.
Fremden gegenüber ist Eiman ein wenig skeptisch und gerät dann auch in Stress. Wir suchen für ihn also ein Zuhause in dem nicht permanent Besuch ein und aus geht. Auch möchten wir Eiman nicht an einen Haushalt mit Kindern vermitteln.

Rio came to us because his owner could no longer care for him due to age. He is initially somewhat reserved around strangers but is friendly with people he knows. He is looking for a home in a quieter environment, perhaps on the outskirts of town.
Rio is prone to stress in the animal shelter and reacts with diarrhea or weight loss – unfortunately, this sensitive male dog is completely out of place in an animal shelter. Therefore, his environment should be low-stimulation and stable. Rio is house-trained, knows basic commands, and can even be left alone for a few hours. He is easy to lead past other dogs and, depending on his affinity, could perhaps even join an existing first dog. He doesn't like cats.
We are looking for a home for Rio with experience with this breed in a house with a fenced yard and no children living in the household. He should no longer have to climb stairs. Please plan several visits to get to know him.
If you are interested in Rio, please contact his animal keepers at +49 30 76888-220 or fill out the contact form below.

The pretty Finja hasn't had a good start in life and was rescued. Despite this, she hasn't lost her courage and is eager to give people trust and love again. She is initially reserved around new people and needs some time to adjust.

The charming Appenzeller mix Tyson found his way to us through one of our member associations. He originally came to the animal shelter because his owner could no longer care for him due to his age.
Tyson can be a bit reserved around strangers at first, but with a few treats, he quickly wins his heart. He occasionally has a mind of his own, but with the right motivation, he can be easily inspired. He gets along well with other dogs, depending on their affinity.

description: Layla, a very active hunting dog mix, is looking for a loving home where she will be appreciated for who she is. She was rescued because her previous owner neglected her. Now she's looking for a new basket and lots of cuddles. There should be no other animals in her new home. The family should not include children under 10 years old, as Lalya, despite her age, can still be very boisterous and sometimes aloof.

Der Mischlingsrüde Miron ist zusammen mit weiteren Hunden aus dem Tierschutzzentrum Odessa in der Ukraine zu uns gekommen.
Im Moment trainieren wir mit ihm das Anlegen von Geschirr und Halsband. Noch kann Miron nicht an der Leine laufen, da ihm die Führung von außen ungewohnt sind. Umso wichtiger ist für ihn ein sicheres, eingezäuntes Grundstück, wo er sich frei bewegen, langsam Vertrauen fassen und seine Umgebung auf seine eigene Art erkunden kann.
Mit Geduld, einem ruhigen Umfeld und klaren Strukturen kann Miron lernen, sich zurechtzufinden und trotz seiner Einschränkung ein erfülltes Leben zu führen. Er benötigt Menschen, die ihn so annehmen wie er ist und ihn auf seinem besonderen Weg begleiten möchten.
Vorgesehen sind mindestens drei Besuche auf dem Sonnenhof. Diese Besuche liegen uns am Herzen, denn in dieser Zeit können Sie Ihren potenziellen Schützling, und er Sie, kennenlernen. Bevor der Hund dann schließlich bei Ihnen einziehen kann, führen wir eine Vorkontrolle bei Ihnen zuhause durch
shelter_name: Sonnenhof für Mensch und Tier, eine Einrichtung vom Deutschen Tierschutzbund e.V.

description:
Marcia is a beautiful dog who previously lived with an animal rights activist in an Italian animal shelter. Unfortunately, this animal shelter had to be closed, so we decided to take Marcia in.
So she came to us in March 2024 with a canine friend. Fortunately, this friend has already found a new home. Now Marcia just needs a forever home.
Because Marcia lived in an Italian animal shelter for a long time, she had little experience with environmental stimuli and life alongside people. She is now gradually making up for this and is learning something new every day with us.
Marcia now reacts very confidently to many things. Nevertheless, there are still situations in which Marcia gets startled and reacts fearfully. The people at her side should be able to accompany her appropriately in these situations (we are happy to advise you on this) and be prepared for Marcia to always be on a leash with a safety harness when walking.

Bruno came to us after being confiscated for violating animal protection laws. He has a deep distrust of people, displays clear aggressive behavior, and has unfortunately even injured people. He is also aggressive towards dogs. Bruno also exhibits resource aggression—he defends food and even a seemingly "worthless" empty bowl. Bruno is undergoing intensive behavioral therapy with us; unfortunately, he is one of our problem dogs.
For this dog, we are looking for a very experienced individual who is willing and able to proactively guide Bruno. He has developed a positive association with his muzzle and wears it well; it must be worn consistently in public. In his new home, Bruno will need a very long adjustment period and a separate room where he can be left, for example, when visitors come. Bruno is very picky about his caregivers; he chooses them very carefully— Not everyone can handle him, even in the animal shelter.
This strong male dog walks well on a leash in quiet surroundings, but he's not at all suitable for the city. Children are also absolutely taboo around him. There's no getting around: Bruno is a difficult candidate. Of course, we're always available to offer advice and support, even after the adoption.
If you meet the requirements and would like to open your heart to Bruno, we look forward to receiving your email with a callback number at tiervermittlung@tierschutz-berlin.de – alternatively, please carefully fill out the form below with all information and explanations. We look forward to your inquiry!

Hello, I'm Olivia
... and unfortunately, I ended up in the animal shelter because I bit someone. 🙁 I'm looking for a home with experience with dogs in a quiet area. Surely there's another chance for me, right?
Would you like to know more about me?
I'm very good at guarding. Well, I protect everything that's "mine." Strangers aren't my cup of tea at all - and when I'm scared, I want to snap. I'm alert, but also very insecure. But I can be left alone for a few hours once I've settled in, and I'm house-trained! I need a muzzle at the vet.

Prinz – Alert, Independent, Vulnerable
Prinz isn't a dog for everyone – but for someone who truly sees him, he can become a special companion. This handsome male was surrendered in September 2023 because his owners were overwhelmed with his care. Previously, he lived on a farm, where he was primarily used as a guard dog.
At first, he wouldn't let anyone near him. It took patience, calm, and a lot of respect until Prinz trusted us and could be examined by a veterinarian. We discovered mild hip dysplasia and an undescended testicle. After neutering, he became noticeably more approachable and relaxed.
We are looking for a ground-floor home for Prinz, free from other animals and small children. He needs a quiet, structured daily routine, clear boundaries—and someone who won't be intimidated but will treat him with understanding and reliability.

Shiva came to us as a surrendered dog.
Shiva originally comes from Romania and is a "typical" Romanian.
Here, we need people who will work with her on a good human-dog relationship and show her that humans can make decisions and that she is not their responsibility, and who will set clear rules and boundaries for her. Then she will become a wonderful everyday companion.
She enjoys going for walks and joins our dog group without any problems.

Sweet three-legged Lenny is looking for patient and loving people who will give him a wonderful home.
Lenny isn't an easy dog and isn't suitable for beginners. He's still skeptical of strangers and insecure in new situations. Lenny now walks well on a leash and tolerates being petted.
Getting to know Lenny should involve several visits. Interested parties should be aware of the time required for the adjustment period and the work that will be required for Lenny.

Male Rex - Labrador Mix - 2 years old, looking for a home
The male Rex did not have a good start in his young life. We know nothing about his first home, except that Rex had an injured tail when he was given away, and it was also shortened. Unfortunately, the agile dog was given to an older man with health problems. Failure was inevitable, as he simply couldn't cope with this dog in terms of strength. And so, failure was practically inevitable, and Rex came to us...
According to his ID card, Rex is a Labrador mix, but we do not know what other breeds are included here. He was born on November 17, 2022, is unneutered, vaccinated, and has a European Pet Passport.
Rex is a friendly dog with people, but not suitable for beginners. He hasn't learned much basic obedience so far, and his leash skills still need improvement. However, he likes to please people. He sits and stays, and he waits for his food. He is content when a person is nearby and then lies relaxed in his place. When we go for walks, he pulls on the leash, but you can hardly blame him, as he hasn't learned it and is so happy to be outside. Rex has a hunting instinct, and it's best not to have cats in his new home. He prefers to catch mice himself...
shelter_name: Tierschutzverein Isenhagener Land im Landkreis Gifhorn e. V.

description: How about you? Aren't I a real sweetheart? I came here from the Berlin animal shelter and am making a fresh start! Because I probably didn't have the best start in life. I always strive to please my humans and am proving myself to be a true nerd. However, I need a home that knows what it wants. Experience with dogs is a must. As long as my humans lead me consistently and straightforwardly, I'll play by the rules. If someone doesn't give me that leadership, I'm quite happy to dance around on their noses. I have a lot to offer, and if you know how to handle me, I'm a lot of fun. Small children shouldn't necessarily live in my new home. I wouldn't mind other dogs, but that would always be decided by mutual sympathy. In general, though, I don't think my fellow dogs are bad.

Elva is a shy and reserved dog looking for someone with plenty of time and patience. She can be kept as a single dog, but would also enjoy a stable first dog. An apartment with an adjoining garden would be ideal, preferably in a rural area. Elva is house-trained and already walks well on a leash. She doesn't like hustle and bustle, and children or cats should not be part of the family.

Cully is a classic livestock guardian dog mix with all the typical characteristics of the breed. She loves her own family and is very affectionate there. Strangers, however, are chased away, sometimes with the use of her teeth. She wears a muzzle when we visit and trusts us to decide who is allowed in and who isn't. However, she needs clear instructions that she is not in charge. She is social with other dogs she knows and enjoys playing. She knows horses and ignores them. She likes to hunt by sight. For example, when chasing butterflies and birds, she can completely forget the world around her if she isn't stopped. Cully generally accepts leadership and boundaries, but asks for more detailed questions and needs people with dog experience. She can open doors, and fences up to 1.30 meters high are no obstacle for her. If she doesn't feel properly guided, she tends to resort to substitute behaviors in the house, such as chasing shadows or reflections of light. She loves children and seeks their company. She now wears a muzzle without any problems and is house-trained. Outside, she responds well to calls with a long leash, and she's already very good at leash handling. If she feels she's not being guided properly, she'll bark at cyclists, walkers, etc. With proper guidance, they'll be ignored. She's also confident in cars and in the city and will accompany you everywhere. She's looking for people who have a securely fenced property, are aware of the characteristics of a livestock guardian dog, and are up to the challenge of meeting her needs. Then Cully will be a pleasant, calm family member.

Our enchanting Noel is a gentle soul in an initially insecure shell. We quickly noticed that this somewhat shy male dog is unfamiliar with many things and finds loud noises particularly spooky.
Once he's warmed up to you, however, he'd prefer not to leave your side. Once Noel has opened up, he's very affectionate and cuddly. He's a fairly quiet type and would certainly enjoy country life. He's definitely not a city dog.
A secure first dog would help him immensely in his forever home, but is not required. A garden is also not required.
Small children should not live in the household. However, if some come to visit occasionally, we don't foresee any problems.
shelter_address: An der Leege, 25 Osterode am Harz, Germany
shelter_name: Tierschutz für Osterode und Umgebung e.V. / Tierheim Osterode

description: Tayla is an attentive, sensitive dog who wants to please. She enjoys going for walks and is very attentive and attentive to her owner; her hunting instinct is rather limited. She prefers playing in a puddle. However, it takes some time to gain her trust; Tayla observes "her people" very closely. It is therefore advisable to plan a few visits to our shelter to get to know them properly. With other dogs, sympathy is key; she is happy as a single dog. Tayla is a livestock guardian dog and clearly does this in "her territory." We are therefore looking for people who can handle this trait and know how to guide her.

Yuki may be a small dog, but he's a big one at heart.
He's always first in line when it comes to petting and food. Otherwise, this young man is brimming with energy and loves to romp around with his fellow dogs. He gets along well with them, even if he can be quite cheeky at times.
His future owners should be prepared for some training, because Yuki knows what he wants and what he doesn't want. In addition to the basic commands, which Yuki still has to learn, there are situations in which he defends resources and would unfortunately use his teeth in the process. We are already training Yuki on this, and his future owners should be willing to continue the training. We will, of course, advise you accordingly.
Yuki walks well on a leash when we go for walks and prefers a more leisurely pace outside. Nevertheless, he also enjoys going for a long walk now and then. Yuki isn't the greatest runner, though. He's also not suited to dog sports. However, this sweet little fellow is very open to other activities and enjoys being mentally stimulated.

Our Rocky was acquired as a puppy because of his breed. But it quickly became clear that the previous owners couldn't do him justice. He was rehomed, but even there, he didn't have an easy time. Ultimately, Rocky was confiscated by the veterinary office, which resulted in him spending a year in a kennel. The owner who took him into his care could no longer devote enough time, but still cares for Rocky intensively here at the shelter. Rocky is now making great progress, is sweet, and knows all the basic commands. During the initial period, the owner, who worked on all of this with him, is happy to help them to ensure a smooth transition. He gets along well with female dogs, but with male dogs, it's all about sympathy. He's also used to life in a household, although he's still a bit boisterous there. Being left alone occasionally is no problem for him. We are therefore looking for experienced owners who are willing to grow and learn together with Rocky.

Merlin is initially skeptical of strangers and needs some time and patience before he opens up to them. However, once he has found a caregiver, he can't get enough of shared walks and cuddles. Unfortunately, Merlin doesn't like driving at all, but we are currently working on this with him.

Our Rottweiler, Diego, has had several owners and is now, unfortunately, visiting us for the second time. He first ended up with us through no fault of his own due to a move.
We quickly found a new home for this handsome fellow – unfortunately, not forever, as it turned out. His second owner couldn't assert herself and assert herself against Diego. Due to a lack of leadership, he asserted his own interests, even using his teeth.
So Diego had to move in with us again. Diego knows all the common basic commands and carries them out reliably. He initially tests his limits with new walkers. With dog experience and the necessary consistency, Diego quickly submits and is a pleasant companion.
He is generally very friendly and seeks contact with people. He enjoys being stroked and scratched extensively and also demands cuddles. Diego behaves exemplary in cars, restaurants, and on public transport. Even longer car rides are no problem for him.

Mira is a soul dog whose partner is still waiting to be found.
In March 2021, the surrendered dog Mira came to our animal shelter after being acquired as a sweet puppy and passed on unloved countless times when it became clear how big she was getting and that, as a Kangal mix, she could definitely have her own unique view of the world.
The first few walks with Mira were more like a tug-of-war, and every other animal in sight was reason enough for another battle of strength, which wasn't due to any ill will, but rather to the fact that her life had certainly been lacking in experiences up to that point.
With a lot of practice, consistency, and routine, the walks became actual walks, and she suddenly revealed a completely different side of herself to "her" people. A sensitive, warm-hearted Mira, who certainly adheres to certain rules and can barely contain her joy when visitors she has taken to her heart arrive. A dog who doesn't necessarily want to be the center of attention, but still enjoys being there and, based on mutual respect, can prove to be a great companion with a very close bond.

Amy was surrendered to us due to aggression. Unfortunately, she has had a history of biting people, and she primarily walks on their heels. Amy also has a problem with resource aggression; she defends her food. In the animal shelter, she is very sensitive to stress and reacts fearfully, especially in new situations. She is not (yet) always predictable and is sometimes aggressive with us. She is only quite obedient towards her caregiver. Amy has been undergoing behavioral therapy with us for months and has made so much progress that she can now be rehomed. However, she will always be a difficult dog who will only go with very knowledgeable people. With us, she is allowed to run around with a few selected dog friends in a small group during the day, but she always wears a muzzle, which she has associated with positive things. In general, she doesn't like other dogs very much (exceptions prove the rule), which is why she will be kept as an only dog in the future.
For Amy, we are looking for very experienced, confident people who have extensive experience with aggression in dogs and can provide the necessary clear leadership and stable structures – these provide security. Amy is not suitable for the city and is also not suitable for children.
If you meet the requirements and are interested in Amy, we look forward to your call at Benji-Haus at +49 30 76888-212 or you can carefully fill out the form below with all the information and explanations. We look forward to your inquiry!

Tango has been found. Unfortunately, we cannot say what his past was like. This impressive male is somewhat insecure upon first meeting and occasionally appears fearful – he probably hasn't always had the best experiences with people and was also handled too roughly. However, once he's warmed up, he loves his caregivers more than anything. He also shows this through his very strong protective instinct. Tango responds well to toys, but can also become cocky and disrespectful once he's gained trust. Attending a good dog school is a prerequisite for channeling his protective instincts and energy.
For the handsome Tango, we are looking for active people with experience with dogs, ideally living in a rural area with a house and garden and having plenty of time for shared activities. Unfortunately, Tango is not suitable for an apartment. This handsome fellow is very alert, typical of the breed, and is also aggressive towards strangers and dogs. Children should not live in the household. Tango must be muzzled whenever he goes outside.
If you would like to meet Tango, you should be prepared for several visits to the animal shelter. A dog trainer would accompany him to the adoption process.
If you have any further questions, please contact his animal caretakers at Benji-Haus at +49 30 76888-212. We look forward to hearing from you!

SOS Forgotten Paws Animal Welfare e.V.
My name is Nala. I was born in 2018 and I'm 45cm tall. For the past three years, I've been alone with my owner since my master passed away. I've developed a very close bond, so strangers are a big challenge for me, and I defend my territory. I now need a good, experienced person by my side who will give me trust and security (behavior training sessions may be necessary). My aggression towards others is a sign of fear and insecurity. I need clear rules and someone who can show me that the world isn't dangerous. You should invest time and patience so that I can open up. Once I've gained trust, I'm very affectionate, cuddly, and love to play. I can stay alone and know basic commands. I get along well with other dogs. There should be no children in my new home. Our foster home cannot keep Nala permanently at the moment, but is looking with us for a suitable, experienced home. If you are interested, you can find out more about Nala at her current foster home - just get in touch with us so we can put you in touch.
I am being placed through the association SOS Vergessene Pfoten Tierschutz e.V. with a protection contract and for a protection fee of 550,- EUR. Of course, I have already been vaccinated, microchipped, dewormed and neutered. I am also already registered with Tasso. You can buy a suitable safety harness, normal harness, collar and leash for me from us in like-new condition. This starter package ensures that I feel safe, secure and well cared for right from the start.
I would like a home full of warmth, understanding and love. Then nothing stands in the way of us becoming best friends for life.
Here comes Jack! This poor guy has been in the Berlin animal shelter for five years. We hope he finally gets a new chance at his own home here!

Rufus has two hearts beating in his chest. On the one hand, he's the absolutely funny, playful, and cuddly clown. On the other hand, he's also the scaredy-cat who can't (yet) assess many things (people, objects, other dogs) and therefore quickly becomes unsettled. Unfortunately, his motto in these situations is: "Attack is the best defense." However, he's becoming increasingly easy to talk to and distract, provided this happens early enough. He actually wants to please, but he's still finding it difficult to abandon his established strategy. If he does something right and you show him, he's incredibly happy, and you can see how proud he is of himself. He's even learned a few basic commands. He already knows sit, stay, and here.

description:
Bubbles unfortunately returned from his trial stay because he showed a lot more there than he has shown here.
Unfortunately, he is a traveling trophy from the classifieds and has had several previous owners in his short life.
Bubbles is very curious, open-minded, but also uninhibited and will go headfirst into something if he finds something interesting.
Bubbles has shown that he can also use his teeth.

Tasmanians are open and friendly dogs toward people.
This describes a behavior in which the dog develops an excessive and obsessive fixation on ball games or toys. These dogs display an extreme addiction to balls/toys, so much so that they lose interest in other things.
He becomes highly aroused as soon as a toy is in sight, which can lead to uncontrolled behavior.
The end of the game leads to stress and restlessness, as he wants to repeat the thrill of the game.

Nagini came to the animal shelter from a confiscated animal. This beautiful young dog has become very friendly with us. While she's initially a bit insecure around strangers, if you give her space and let her decide for herself when she wants to make contact, the ice quickly breaks, and Nagini reveals her cuddly side.
The Alabai, or Central Asian Shepherd Dog, is a herd protector. These dogs cannot be handled by just anyone; they need dedicated caregivers who guide the dog with confident composure. Physically, herd protectors like Nagini are very strong. They were bred to protect grazing animals from large attackers, such as wolves. This requires courage and decisiveness, which is why herd protectors tend to quickly step forward when they feel threatened.
Due to her breed, Nagini will only be adopted by people with a lot of dog experience (ideally, herd protectors) and a house and garden. Whether she gets along with other dogs depends on how well they interact. Older, sensible children, about 12 years and older, are no problem for her.
If you would like to get to know our wonderful Nagini, please plan several visits. If you are interested or have any questions, please contact her animal caretakers at Struppi-Haus by phone at +49 30 76888-156. We look forward to hearing from you!

Tommy Junior, a.k.a. TJ, came to our shelter after being confiscated for violating animal protection laws. So far, he has been very distrustful of people. Unfortunately, he has experienced biting incidents with humans and his former owners in the past. Currently, he doesn't (yet) accept anyone approaching his caregiver or his basket. He also defends his food and bowls.
TJ is therefore looking for people with experience with dogs who can come to us frequently to get to know him. TJ walks well on a leash and doesn't often bully other dogs. He knows basic commands and is also comfortable riding in a car. We suspect he can be left alone for a few hours.
For our TJ, we are looking for very confident, experienced people who can offer him security and structure with clear rules. He needs a quiet home, preferably on the ground floor, as he has orthopedic problems. There should be no children in the household. Please note that due to his breed, TJ is subject to muzzle and leash requirements in Berlin, and landlord approval is required for his ownership.
Would you like to give our TJ a chance or do you have any questions? Please fill out the form below. We look forward to hearing from you.

Bali originally came from Taiwan and was given up here by his owners because they were overwhelmed with him. He is house-trained, knows basic commands, and calmly walks past other dogs. Whether he can be left alone will need to be tested and, if necessary, patiently trained.
Bali is a true prince of one's own; he dislikes other dogs at all. If they come too close, he might snap. He is very insecure and skeptical of strangers. Here, too, he would snap if someone came too close. Unfortunately, this has led to biting incidents. However, once he gains trust, he is very friendly to people he knows.
For Bali, we are looking for people who have experience with foreign dogs and know how to handle him defending resources. His new home should be in a quieter location, away from a noisy urban area. Ideally, he will have a securely fenced garden where he can run around. Bali also has a strong hunting instinct, which is why imitation hunting games are not for him. Children should not live in the household. Please note that several visits to get to know Bali will be necessary.
If you would like to give Bali a loving home or have any questions about him, please contact his keepers by phone at +49 30 76888-264 or fill out the inquiry form below.

SOS Forgotten Paws e.V.
Dear paw friends, my name is Jasko and I was born in mid-2020. At 55 cm at the shoulder, I am a stately male - black as night, with a white chest and a faithful gaze that hits you right in the heart. And what else do I have? A real character dog - friendly, cuddly but with a lot of energy. I love long walks, I love being outdoors, but I also enjoy cuddling with my humans. When it comes to my fellow dogs, especially (males), I decide based on sympathy - I'm not a follower, but a (single) dog with personality. Children should be older and stable in my new home, because I'm a strong guy with power. Things can get a bit boisterous when playing or greeting people. What am I still missing? Loving people with experience with dogs who can guide me, give me security, and are eager to go through life with me. I bring a lot of love – and if the chemistry is right, you'll find a loyal companion for life in me.
I will be rehomed with a protection contract and for a protection fee of €550. I am, of course, vaccinated, microchipped, dewormed, neutered, and already registered with Tasso. You can purchase a matching safety harness, regular harness, collar, and leash from us in like-new condition. This starter package ensures that I feel safe, secure, and well cared for right from the start.
Interested? Then I look forward to getting to know you! You are welcome to visit me by appointment to give me a forever basket.

Speedy - a sensitive companion with potential!
Speedy has unfortunately had bad experiences with men in the past, which is why we would prefer to place him in a female household.
It is important to pay attention to his body language and respect his boundaries. There have been several biting incidents in the past, so his new owner should be experienced with dogs and be able to lead him confidently.
Speedy is an intelligent dog who loves learning new things. He particularly enjoys nose work and is a great way to stimulate his mind. He has a slight hunting instinct, which is why off-leash running is only possible with appropriate security. He's used to wearing a muzzle and should continue to wear it in certain situations.

My name is Aron, I'm a spry old dog and I'm urgently looking for a home!
After the auto repair shop I was allowed to guard for almost my entire life was sold, I had to go to the animal shelter. I've been sitting here since October 2024 and I don't understand what's going on. Everyday life in the animal shelter is extremely stressful for me. This manifests itself in the fact that I bark incessantly in my kennel because I just want to be with people. Furthermore, all the stress is really upsetting my stomach, so I've lost (too) many pounds. My keepers are very worried about me because they're afraid I'll starve to death from a full bowl. The animal shelter also diagnosed me with hypothyroidism and pancreatitis. Both are well controlled with medication and special food.
I generally get along well with other dogs, but I would still like a home or a foster home as a single prince, as I really enjoy spending a lot of time with my humans. Encounters with dogs on a leash are a big challenge for me, as I used to have to keep intruders away as a guard dog. My regular dog walker is already working hard on this with me.
An overnight trip to my regular dog walker showed that I calm down quite quickly after a bit of excitement indoors. My greatest wish is a comfortable basket with loving people who have plenty of time and perhaps some German Shepherd experience in a quiet, rural area, where I can finally settle in and enjoy my retirement. Children are not a problem either, but ideally they should already be teenagers so that they can grow up to me physically. I love long walks in nature and, despite my age, I'm still pretty fit and agile.

My name is Aska, and I came to the Schwebheim shelter via another animal shelter. I've proven myself to be very outgoing, cuddly, and people-oriented. As is typical for my breed, I'm very agile and like to be kept busy. Larger, stable children would be no problem for me. I get along well with male dogs, but with female dogs, it's a matter of mutual sympathy. Cats still need to be tested. Because I suffer from an eye condition, I'm not allowed in direct sunlight and wear sunglasses when I go for walks.

It's urgent: The cheerful Tommy has to move because his owner is seriously ill and can no longer keep him. Tommy can't be kept busy enough to keep him active and is suffering from the situation.
Tommy needs training and guidance when interacting with other dogs - he's friendly, but his 50 kg weight really wants to be with other dogs. Not every dog is happy about that...
Tommy can be met in Göttingen; we will forward inquiries immediately. He isn't at our dog park yet - he should stay with his owner as long as possible. It's very urgent so he doesn't have to move into our animal shelter.
